lines.value: leonidas leon jaworski september 19 1905 - december 9 1982 was an american attorney and law professor who served as the second special prosecutor during the watergate scandal
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was appointed to that position on november 1 1973 soon after the saturday night massacre of october 19 20 1973 that resulted in the dismissal of his predecessor archibald cox
lines.name: English

lines.value: jaworski was born in waco in central texas a child of german speaking parents his mother marie mira was an austrian immigrant and his father joseph jaworski was a polish immigrant who was an evangelical minister
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was named after ancient spartan king leonidas and had a brother named hannibal
lines.name: English

lines.value: an earnest student who studied at night by the light of oil lamps he was a champion debater at waco high school and graduated from baylor law school and received his master's degree in law at the george washington university law school in washington dc
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1925 he became the youngest person ever admitted to the texas bar
lines.name: English

lines.value: after starting out defending bootleggers during prohibition in 1931 he joined the houston law firm that became fulbright & jaworski one of the largest law firms in the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: jaworski served as president of both the texas bar association 1962-1963 and the american bar association 1971-1972 prior to his appointment as special prosecutor
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was also president of the houston chamber of commerce in 1960 and served on many corporate and civic boards
lines.name: English

lines.value: during world war ii jaworski prosecuted the johannes kunze murder trial where five german prisoners of war were accused of beating a fellow prisoner to death for being a traitor
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the night of august 14 1944 the fort lawton riot between african american us soldiers and italian prisoners of war at fort lawton near seattle resulted in the lynching of italian prisoner of war guglielmo olivotto
lines.name: English

lines.value: thereafter jaworski prosecuted forty three african american soldiers of whom twenty eight were convicted in what was the longest us army court martial of world war ii
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2005 the us army board for correction of military records ordered all those convictions reversed on the grounds that jaworski had committed egregious error
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the war jaworski served as a war crimes prosecutor in germany
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was involved in a case where eleven german civilians were accused of murdering six american airmen forced down over germany in the russelsheim massacre
lines.name: English

lines.value: however he declined to participate in the nuremberg trials on the grounds that the prosecution there was based on laws that did not exist at the time of the culpable acts
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was a friend of fellow texan lyndon baines johnson whom he successfully represented in a 1960 lawsuit filed to prevent johnson from campaigning for the us senate against republican john tower at the same time that johnson was running for vice president of the united states on the john f kennedy ticket
lines.name: English

lines.value: however jaworski did not always support democratic candidates
lines.name: English

lines.value: he supported richard nixon and voted for him twice contributed to george hw bush in his campaign for the presidency in 1980 and after bush conceded the nomination he became treasurer of democrats for reagan during the 1980 general election campaign
lines.name: English

lines.value: having been convinced of his integrity in 1980 jaworski aided former nixon staffer egil bud krogh whom he had sent to prison in 1973 in krogh's request to be reinstated to the bar in washington state
lines.name: English

lines.value: jaworski's greatest fame came from his tenure as watergate special prosecutor when he assumed leadership of a protracted contest with president nixon to secure evidence for the trial of former senior administration officials on charges relating to the watergate cover up
lines.name: English

lines.value: jaworski's predecessor as special prosecutor archibald cox initially believed that only nixon's aides had committed misconduct
lines.name: English

lines.value: because of testimony from nixon's deputy assistant alexander butterfield cox learned that nixon had discussed the watergate cover up with the accused on numerous occasions and that these conversations had been recorded by the white house taping system
lines.name: English

lines.value: this discovery caused cox to subpoena tapes of sixty four presidential conversations as evidence for the upcoming criminal trial but nixon refused to release them citing executive privilege
lines.name: English

lines.value: nixon offered cox what became known as the stennis compromise instead of supplying the tapes he would supply cox with transcripts of the recordings subject to nixon's discretion and allow one senator to listen to the recordings and verify the transcripts accuracy
lines.name: English

lines.value: cox rejected the compromise whereupon nixon fired cox in the saturday night massacre
lines.name: English

lines.value: under extreme criticism for the firing nixon appointed jaworski to replace cox
lines.name: English

lines.value: jaworski subsequently subpoenaed sixty four taped conversations
lines.name: English

lines.value: nixon appealed on two grounds first that the office of special prosecutor did not have the right to sue the office of president and second that the requested materials were privileged presidential conversations
lines.name: English

lines.value: aware that an important constitutional issue was at stake and unwilling to wait any longer jaworski asked the supreme court to take the case directly bypassing the court of appeals
lines.name: English

lines.value: on july 24 1974 the supreme court ruled that the special prosecutor did have the right to sue the president and that the generalized assertion of [executive] privilege must yield to the demonstrated specific need for evidence in a pending criminal trial
lines.name: English

lines.value: nixon was forced to give the unedited tapes to jaworski including the so called smoking gun tape which included a compromising discussion of june 23 1972
lines.name: English

lines.value: the president's remaining support waned and he resigned on august 9 1974
lines.name: English

lines.value: jaworski resigned as special prosecutor on october 25 1974 once the cover up trial had begun and a new special prosecutor was appointed
lines.name: English

lines.value: jaworski was a close friend of dean ernest raba of st mary's university school of law in san antonio where he taught as an adjunct professor for several years
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1977 jaworski reluctantly agreed to serve as special counsel to a house ethics committee investigation to determine whether members had indirectly or directly accepted anything of value from the government of the republic of korea
lines.name: English

lines.value: the investigation known as koreagate or the tongsun park investigation potentially involved hundreds of members of congress and their families and associates and included charges of bribery and influence peddling via envelopes stuffed with $100 bills
lines.name: English

lines.value: jaworski died on december 9 1982 while chopping wood at the circle j ranch near wimberley in hays county texas
lines.name: English

lines.value: his wife died in 1999
lines.name: English

lines.value: nikola subic zrinski ( ) or zrinyi miklos () 1508 - 7 september 1566 was a croatian nobleman and general in the service of the habsburg ban of croatia from 1542-56 and member of the zrinski noble family
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was known across europe for his involvement in the siege of szigetvar and is today seen as a hero by both hungarians and croats
lines.name: English

lines.value: nikola was born in 1508 as the son of nikola iii zrinski and jelena karlovic sister of future croatian ban ivan karlovic he distinguished himself at the siege of vienna in 1529
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1542 he saved the imperial army from defeat before pest by intervening with 400 croats for which service he was appointed ban of croatia
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1542 he routed an ottoman force at the battle of somlyo
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1543 he married katarina frankopan a sister of count stjepan frankopan ozaljski stephen frankopan of ozalj in english who placed the whole of her vast estates at his disposal
lines.name: English

lines.value: she bore him many children among which was his successor juraj iv zrinski
lines.name: English

lines.value: the king ferdinand i gave him large possessions in hungary and croatia and henceforth the zrinskis zrinyis became as much magyar as croatian magnates
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a compensation for his battles with the ottomans he was granted the whole area of medimurje murakoz on 12 march 1546 from king ferdinand hence the centre of the zrinski family has moved from zrin to the city of cakovec csaktornya where he rearranged the existing castle
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1556 zrinski won a series of victories over the ottomans culminating in the battle of babocsa and thus preventing the fall of szigetvar
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1563 on the coronation of the emperor maximilian as king of hungary zrinski attended the ceremony at the head of 3000 croatian and magyar mounted noblemen in the vain hope of obtaining the dignity of palatine vacant by the death of tamas nadasdy
lines.name: English

lines.value: shortly after marrying in 1564 his second wife eva of rozmberk rosenberg a bohemian heiress he hastened southwards to defend the frontier and defeated the ottomans at szeged
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1566 from 5 august to 7 september his small force 2300 soldiers heroically defended the small fortress of szigetvar against the whole ottoman host 102000 soldiers led by suleiman the magnificent in person
lines.name: English

lines.value: the siege of szigetvar ended with every remaining member of the garrison including subic zrinski in a last desperate sortie
lines.name: English

lines.value: suleiman the magnificent had died from a cerebral hemorrhage one day before the ottomans won the battle
lines.name: English

lines.value: nikola subic zrinski was the great grandfather of croatian ban viceroy and croatian/hungarian poet miklos zrinyi as well as his younger brother petar zrinski
lines.name: English

lines.value: the former wrote the hungarian epic poem the peril of sziget of which the elder zrinski is the hero which has assured zrinski's place in hungarian culture
lines.name: English

lines.value: the epic remains in print today and is considered one of the landmarks of hungarian literature
lines.name: English

lines.value: a park in zagreb is named trg nikole subica zrinskog after him
lines.name: English

lines.value: zrinski's last battle was made the subject of a tragedy zrinyi ein trauerspiel by theodor korner
lines.name: English

lines.value: the order of nikola subic zrinski is the eighth ranked honour order given by the republic of croatia
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is awarded to croatian or foreign citizens for acts of heroism
lines.name: English

lines.value: recipients include 47 military units of the croatian armed forces for valor in the croatian war of independence
lines.name: English

lines.value: a petition is a request to do something most commonly addressed to a government official or public entity
lines.name: English

lines.value: petitions to a deity are a form of prayer called supplication
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the colloquial sense a petition is a document addressed to some official and signed by numerous individuals
lines.name: English

lines.value: a petition may be oral rather than written or may be transmitted via the internet
lines.name: English

lines.value: petition can also be the title of a legal pleading that initiates a legal case
lines.name: English

lines.value: the initial pleading in a civil lawsuit that seeks only money damages might be called in most us courts a complaint
lines.name: English

lines.value: an initial pleading in a lawsuit that seeks non monetary or equitable relief such as a request for a writ of mandamus or habeas corpus custody of a child or probate of a will is instead called a petition
lines.name: English

lines.value: act on petition is a summary process used in probate ecclesiastical and divorce cases designed to handle matters which are too complex for simple motion
lines.name: English

lines.value: the parties in a case exchange pleadings until a cause for a hearing is settled
lines.name: English

lines.value: black's law dictionary specifies it as an obsolete method used in admiralty cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the united states the act on petition has been used in maritime cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: in pre modern imperial china petitions were always sent to an office of transmission tongzheng si or 通政司 where court secretaries read petitions aloud to the emperor
lines.name: English

lines.value: petitions could be sent by anybody from a scholar official to a common farmer although the petitions were more likely read to the emperor if they were persuasive enough to impeach questionable and corrupt local officials from office
lines.name: English

lines.value: when petitions arrived to the throne multiple copies were made of the original and stored with the office of supervising secretaries before the original written petition was sent to the emperor
lines.name: English

lines.value: petitions were a common form of protest and request to the british house of commons in the 18th and 19th centuries the largest being the great/people's charter or petition of the chartists
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are still presented in small numbers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the petition clause of the first amendment to the us constitution guarantees the right of the people to petition the government for a redress of grievances the right to petition has been held to include the right to file lawsuits against the government
lines.name: English

lines.value: petitions are commonly used in the us to qualify candidates for public office to appear on a ballot while anyone can be a write in candidate a candidate desiring that his or her name appear on printed ballots and other official election materials must gather a certain number of valid signatures from registered voters
lines.name: English

lines.value: in jurisdictions whose laws allow for ballot initiatives the gathering of a sufficient number of voter signatures qualilfies a proposed initiative to be placed on the ballot
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 2003 california recall election which culminated in the recall of governor gray davis and the election of arnold schwarzenegger began when us representative darrell issa employed paid signature gatherers who obtained millions of signatures at a cost to issa of millions of dollars
lines.name: English

lines.value: once the requisite number of signatures was obtained on the recall petition other petitions were circulated by would be candidates who wanted to appear on the ballot as possible replacements for davis
lines.name: English

lines.value: after that step a vote on the recall was scheduled
lines.name: English

lines.value: other types of petitions include those that sought to free nelson mandela during his imprisonment by the former apartheid government of south africa
lines.name: English

lines.value: the petitions had no legal effect but the signatures of millions of people on the petitions represented a moral force that may have helped free mandela and end apartheid
lines.name: English

lines.value: non governmental organizations such as amnesty international often use petitions in an attempt to exert moral authority in support of various causes
lines.name: English

lines.value: other nongovernmental subjects of petition drives include corporate personnel decisions
lines.name: English

lines.value: internet petition is a new form of a petition becoming commonplace in the 21st century
lines.name: English

lines.value: change.org is the world's most popular online petition platform that has 50 million registered users
lines.name: English

lines.value: recent research by the sociocultural psychologist chana etengoff has highlighted the therapeutic benefits of petitioning including meaning making social action agency and empowerment
lines.name: English

lines.value: the congres internationaux d'architecture moderne ciam or international congresses of modern architecture was an organization founded in 1928 and disbanded in 1959 responsible for a series of events and congresses arranged across europe by the most prominent architects of the time with the objective of spreading the principles of the modern movement focusing in all the main domains of architecture such as landscape urbanism industrial design and many others
lines.name: English

lines.value: the international congresses of modern architecture ciam was founded in june 1928 at the chateau de la sarraz in switzerland by a group of 28 european architects organized by le corbusier helene de mandrot owner of the castle and sigfried giedion the first secretary general
lines.name: English

lines.value: ciam was one of many 20th century manifestos meant to advance the cause of architecture as a social art
lines.name: English

lines.value: other founder members included karl moser first president hendrik berlage victor bourgeois pierre chareau sven markelius josef frank gabriel guevrekian max ernst haefeli hugo haring arnold hochel huib hoste pierre jeanneret cousin of le corbusier andre lurcat ernst may max cetto fernando garcia mercadal hannes meyer werner m moser carlo enrico rava gerrit rietveld alberto sartoris hans schmidt mart stam rudolf steiger szymon syrkus henri robert von der muhll and juan de zavala
lines.name: English

lines.value: the soviet delegates were to be el lissitzky nikolai kolli and moisei ginzburg although at the sarraz conference they were unable to obtain visas
lines.name: English

lines.value: other later members included minnette de silva walter gropius alvar aalto uno ahren louis herman de koninck 1929 and fred forbat
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1941 harwell hamilton harris was chosen as secretary of the american branch of ciam which was the chapter for relief and post war planning founded in new york city
lines.name: English

lines.value: josep lluis sert co founder of gatepac and gatcpac in saragoza and barcelona respectively in 1930 as well as adlan friends of new art in barcelona in 1932 participated in the congresses as of 1929 and served as ciam president from 1947 to 1956
lines.name: English

lines.value: the organization was hugely influential
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was not only engaged in formalizing the architectural principles of the modern movement but also saw architecture as an economic and political tool that could be used to improve the world through the design of buildings and through urban planning
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fourth ciam meeting in 1933 was to have been held in moscow
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rejection of le corbusier's competition entry for the palace of the soviets a watershed moment and an indication that the soviets had abandoned ciam's principles changed those plans
lines.name: English

lines.value: instead it was held onboard ship the ss patris ii which sailed from marseille to athens
lines.name: English

lines.value: here the group discussed the principles of the functional city which broadened ciam's scope from architecture into urban planning
lines.name: English

lines.value: based on an analysis of thirty three cities ciam proposed that the social problems faced by cities could be resolved by strict functional segregation and the distribution of the population into tall apartment blocks at widely spaced intervals
lines.name: English

lines.value: these proceedings went unpublished from 1933 until 1943 when le corbusier acting alone published them in heavily edited form as the athens charter as ciam members traveled worldwide after the war many of its ideas spread outside europe notably to the usa
lines.name: English

lines.value: the city planning ideas were adopted in the rebuilding of europe following world war ii although by then some ciam members had their doubts
lines.name: English

lines.value: alison and peter smithson were chief among the dissenters
lines.name: English

lines.value: when implemented in the postwar period many of these ideas were compromised by tight financial constraints poor understanding of the concepts or popular resistance
lines.name: English

lines.value: mart stam's replanning of postwar dresden in the ciam formula was rejected by its citizens as an all out attack on the city the ciam organization disbanded in 1959 as the views of the members diverged
lines.name: English

lines.value: le corbusier had left in 1955 objecting to the increasing use of english during meetings
lines.name: English

lines.value: for a reform of ciam the group team 10 was active from 1953 onwards and two different movements emerged from it the new brutalism of the english members alison and peter smithson and the structuralism of the dutch members aldo van eyck and jacob b bakema
lines.name: English

lines.value: the elected executive body of ciam was cirpac the comite international pour la resolution des problemes de l'architecture contemporaine international committee for the resolution of problems in contemporary architecture
lines.name: English

lines.value: the atlantic spotted dolphin stenella frontalis is a dolphin found in the gulf stream of the north atlantic ocean
lines.name: English

lines.value: older members of the species have a very distinctive spotted coloration all over their bodies
lines.name: English

lines.value: the atlantic spotted dolphin was first described by cuvier in 1828
lines.name: English

lines.value: considerable variation in the physical form of individuals occurs in the species and specialists have long been uncertain as to the correct taxonomic classification
lines.name: English

lines.value: currently just one species is recognised but a large particularly spotty variant commonly found near florida quite possibly may be classified as a formal subspecies or indeed a species in its own right
lines.name: English

lines.value: atlantic spotted dolphins in the bahamas have been observed mating with bottlenose dolphins
lines.name: English

lines.value: rich leduc has published data that suggest the atlantic spotted dolphin may be more closely related to bottlenose dolphin genus tursiops than to other members of the genus stenella
lines.name: English

lines.value: the coloring of the atlantic spotted dolphin varies enormously as it grows and is usually classified into age dependent phases known as two tone speckled mottled and fused
lines.name: English

lines.value: calves are a fairly uniform gray white with one or no spots
lines.name: English

lines.value: when they are weaned speckling occurs typically between 3 and 4 years and lasting for an average of 5 years
lines.name: English

lines.value: a juvenile is considered mottled when it develops merging gray and white spots on the dorsal surface and black spots on the ventral surface
lines.name: English

lines.value: this usually happens between age 8 or 9
lines.name: English

lines.value: a fused pattern is reached when dark and white spots are on both the ventral and dorsal sides
lines.name: English

lines.value: as the animal matures the spots become denser and spread until the body appears black with white spots at full maturation
lines.name: English

lines.value: in comparison to other dolphin species the atlantic spotted dolphin is medium sized
lines.name: English

lines.value: newborn calves are about long while adults can reach a length of and a weight of in males and and in females
lines.name: English

lines.value: compared to the much smaller pantropical spotted dolphin the atlantic spotted dolphin is more robust
lines.name: English

lines.value: it shares its habitat with the pantropical spotted dolphin and the bottlenose dolphin
lines.name: English

lines.value: the species exhibits a range of about ten different vocalizations in cluding whistles buzzes squawks and barks each corresponding with different behaviors
lines.name: English

lines.value: atlantic spotted dolphins are extremely gregarious animals which gather in complex social groups of 5-15 often in mixed groups with common bottlenose dolphins
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are fast swimmers and known for their bow riding and long shallow leaping behaviors
lines.name: English

lines.value: their mating system consists of one male mating with several females and the pod is highly protective over pregnant females
lines.name: English

lines.value: the dolphin's gestational period is ~11 months and the mother cares for its calf for up to 5 years with the help of the rest of her group
lines.name: English

lines.value: these animals are cooperative hunters that hunt in groups at night
lines.name: English

lines.value: they strategically encircle their prey which consists mostly of small fish benthic invertebrates and cephalopods such as squid
lines.name: English

lines.value: they can dive to depths of up to 60 m and can stay beneath the surface for up to 10 minutes at a time
lines.name: English

lines.value: the species is endemic to the temperate and tropical areas of the atlantic ocean
lines.name: English

lines.value: it has been widely observed in the western end of the gulf stream between florida and bermuda
lines.name: English

lines.value: off the bahamas tourism industries to swim with dolphins are available
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is also present in the gulf of mexico
lines.name: English

lines.value: more infrequent sightings have been made further east off the azores and canary islands
lines.name: English

lines.value: northerly sightings have been made as far north as cape cod across to the southwestern tip of spain
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are certainly present further south too as far as rio grande do sul in brazil and across to west africa but their distribution is poorly understood in these areas
lines.name: English

lines.value: about 20 years ago only about 80 dolphins were in the bahamas
lines.name: English

lines.value: now almost 200 dolphins are found there
lines.name: English

lines.value: on account of their similar appearance to other dolphins in their range it is difficult to be sure of the atlantic spotted dolphin's population
lines.name: English

lines.value: a conservative estimate is around 100000 individuals
lines.name: English

lines.value: some atlantic spotted dolphins particularly some of those are around the bahamas have become habituated to human contact
lines.name: English

lines.value: in these areas cruises to watch and even swim with the dolphins are common
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are usually not held in captivity
lines.name: English

lines.value: atlantic spotted dolphins are an occasional target of harpoon fishermen and every year some creatures are trapped and killed in gill nets but these activities are not currently believed to be threatening the survival of the species
lines.name: English

lines.value: this species lives in the mesopelagic layer of the ocean
lines.name: English

lines.value: these dolphins are not threatened by extinction however commercial trade may affect their evolution and sustainability
lines.name: English

lines.value: sometimes they are killed by harpoons off st vincent
lines.name: English

lines.value: the atlantic spotted dolphin is included in the memorandum of understanding concerning the conservation of the manatee and small cetaceans of western africa and macaronesia
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are also marked as dd data deficient of the conservation action plan for the world's cetaceans
lines.name: English

lines.value: :'this article is about diplomacy
lines.name: English

lines.value: for the blue oyster cult album see secret treaties a secret treaty is an international agreement in which the contracting parties have agreed either in the treaty instrument or separately to conceal its existence or at least its substance from other states and the public according to one compilation of secret treaties published in 2004 there have been 593 secret treaties negotiated by 110 countries and independent political entities since the year 1521
lines.name: English

lines.value: secret treaties were a central instrument of balance of power diplomacy in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries but are rare today
lines.name: English

lines.value: the elaborate alliance systems among european powers each secured by a network of secret treaties financial arrangements and military understandings are commonly cited as one of the causes of world war i for example the reinsurance treaty of june 1887 between the german empire and the russian empire negotiated by german chancellor otto von bismarck in order for germany to avoid a two front war was a highly secret treaty in which the two powers pledged a three year period to remain neutral should the other become involved in a war with a third country unless germany attacked russia's longstanding ally france or russia attacked germany's longstanding ally austria hungary
lines.name: English

lines.value: the use of secret agreements and undertakings between several allies or between one state and another continued throughout world war i some of them were irreconcilably inconsistent leaving a bitter legacy of dispute at the end of the war
lines.name: English

lines.value: some important secret treaties of this era include the secretly concluded treaty of ottoman german alliance concluded at constantinople on august 2 1914

lines.value: that treaty provided that germany and turkey would remain neutral in the conflict between austria hungary and serbia but if russia intervened with active military measures the two countries would become military allies
lines.name: English

lines.value: another important secret treaty was the treaty of london concluded on april 26 1915 in which italy was promised certain territorial concessions in exchange for joining the war on the triple entente allied side
lines.name: English

lines.value: another secret treaty was the treaty of bucharest concluded between romania and the triple entente powers britain france italy and russia on august 17 1916 under this treaty romania pledged to attack austria hungary and not to seek a separate peace in exchange for certain territorial gains
lines.name: English

lines.value: article 16 of that treaty provided that the present arrangement shall be held secret

lines.value: after the outbreak of world war i public opinion in many countries demanded more open diplomacy

lines.value: after the october revolution brought the bolsheviks to power in russia in november 1917 leon trotsky published the secret treaties that the tsarist government had made with the entente powers including the treaty of london and the constantinople agreement
lines.name: English

lines.value: he proposed the abolition of secret diplomacy
lines.name: English

lines.value: this move caused international embarrassment and a strong sustained reaction against secret diplomacy us president woodrow wilson was an opponent of secret diplomacy viewing it as a threat to peace
lines.name: English

lines.value: he made the abolition of secret diplomacy the first point of his fourteen points set forth in a speech to congress on january 8 1918 after the us entered the war
lines.name: English

lines.value: wilson dissociated the united states from the allies earlier secret commitments and sought to abolish them forever once the war had been won the fourteen points were based on a draft paper prepared by walter lippmann and his colleagues on the inquiry isaiah bowman sidney mezes and david hunter miller
lines.name: English

lines.value: lippmann's draft was a direct response to the secret treaties which lippman had been shown by secretary of war newton d baker
lines.name: English

lines.value: lippman's task was to take the secret treaties analyze the parts which were tolerable and separate them from those which we regarded as intolerable and then develop a position which conceded as much to the allies as it could but took away the poison
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was all keyed upon the secret treaties
lines.name: English

lines.value: that's what decided what went into the fourteen points wilson repeated his fourteen points at the versailles peace conference where he proposed a commitment to open covenants openly arrived at and the elimination of private international understandings of any kind [so that] diplomacy shall proceed always frankly and in the public view the wilsonian position was codified in article 18 of the covenant of the league of nations which mandated that all league of nations members states register every treaty or international agreement with the league secretariat and that no treaty was binding unless so registered
lines.name: English

lines.value: this led to the rise of the treaty registration system although not every treaty that would have been subject to registration was duly registered
lines.name: English

lines.value: ironically one of the major secret treaties of the interwar period took place against a league of nations background
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1935 mussolini's italy was determined to annex abyssinia ethiopia and the league attempted to moderate between the two countries with little success
lines.name: English

lines.value: in october british foreign secretary samuel hoare made a secret plan with french prime minister pierre laval to give away most of abyssinia's territory to mussolini
lines.name: English

lines.value: two months later news leaked out about the hoare laval pact and the two politicians were forced from power amid public outrage
lines.name: English

lines.value: the scheme had been based on a 1906 secret treaty which carved up ethiopia among the european powers without its knowledge
lines.name: English

lines.value: the episode severely damaged the reputation of the league
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of the most infamous secret treaties in history was the secret additional protocol to the molotov ribbentrop pact of august 23 1939 between soviet union and nazi germany negotiated by soviet foreign minister vyacheslav molotov and german foreign minister joachim von ribbentrop
lines.name: English

lines.value: the pact itself a ten year nonaggression agreement was public but the additional secret protocol superseded by a similar subsequent secret protocol the german soviet frontier treaty the next month carved up spheres of influence in eastern europe between nazi germany and the soviet union placing finland estonia latvia bessarabia part of romania and eastern poland in the soviet sphere and western poland and lithuania in the german sphere
lines.name: English

lines.value: the existence of the secret protocol was not revealed until 1989 when it became public it caused outrage in the baltic states
lines.name: English

lines.value: the percentages agreement was a secret pact between soviet premier joseph stalin and british prime minister winston churchill during the fourth moscow conference on undefined undefined undefined about how to divide various european countries among the leader's respective spheres of influence
lines.name: English

lines.value: the agreement was officially made public by churchill twelve years later in the final volume of his memoir of the second world war
lines.name: English

lines.value: after world war ii the registration system that had begun with the league of nations was continued through the united nations
lines.name: English

lines.value: article 102 of the charter of the united nations based on article 18 of the covenant of the league of nations provides that over the years the un has developed an extensive treaty registration system detailed in its repertory of practice and treaty handbook
lines.name: English

lines.value: from december 1946 through july 2013 the united nations secretariat recorded over 200000 treaties published in the united nations treaty series pursuant to article 102 of the un charter
lines.name: English

lines.value: still today a substantial number of treaties are not registered mainly due to practical reasons such as the administrative or ephemeral charter of some treaties non registered treaties are not necessarily secret since such treaties are often published elsewhere

lines.value: some true secret treaties still exist however mostly in the context of agreements to establish foreign military bases

lines.value: for example after the 1960 security treaty between the us and japan the two nations entered into three agreements that according to an expert panel convened by the japanese foreign ministry could defined as secret treaties at least in a broad sense

lines.name: English

lines.value: prior to their public release in 2010 the japanese government had gone so far as convicting journalist nishiyama takichi who tried to expose one treaty for espionage

lines.value: operation condor was a secret treaty between the us and five south american nations to coordinate counter insurgency and dirty war against communist rebels and other leftists in latin america
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to dorr & schmalenbach's commentary on the vienna convention on the law of treaties the fact that today secret treaties do not play an essential role is less a result of [article 102 of the un charter] than of an overall change in the conduct of international relations according to charles lipson with private international understandings virtually eliminated among democratic states informal agreements live on as their closest modern substitutes
lines.name: English

lines.value: secret treaties in which the agreement itself is secret are distinct from secret negotiations in which the ongoing negotiations are confidential but the final agreement is public

lines.value: colin warbrick writes that in britain the prerogative power to negotiate and conclude treaties puts the government in a powerful position
lines.name: English

lines.value: it does not need to seek a negotiating mandate from parliament and can keep its positions confidential until the conclusion of negotiations the traditional rule in favor of secrecy of negotiations is in tension with values of transparency anne peters writes that the growing significance of multilateral treaties as global instruments invites a readjustment of the relative weight accorded to the values of discreteness and confidentiality of diplomatic treaty negotiations on one hand and the interests of third parties and the global public on the other hand the secrecy of negotiations for free trade agreements such as the trans pacific partnership and the anti counterfeiting trade agreement have been politically controversial with some commentators favoring greater transparency and others emphasizing the need for confidentiality

lines.value: irene amos morgan april 9 1917 - august 10 2007 later known as irene morgan kirkaldy was an african american woman from baltimore maryland who was arrested in middlesex county virginia in 1944 under a state law imposing racial segregation in public facilities and transportation
lines.name: English

lines.value: she was traveling on an interstate bus that operated under federal law and regulations
lines.name: English

lines.value: she refused to give up her seat in what the driver said was the white section
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the time she worked for a defense contractor on the production line for b 26 marauders
lines.name: English

lines.value: morgan consulted with attorneys to appeal her conviction and the naacp legal defense fund took up her case
lines.name: English

lines.value: she was represented by william h hastie the former governor of the us virgin islands and later a judge on the us court of appeals for the third circuit and thurgood marshall legal counsel of the naacp her case irene morgan v commonwealth of virginia was appealed to the united states supreme court
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1946 in a landmark decision the court ruled that the virginia law was unconstitutional as the commerce clause protected interstate traffic
lines.name: English

lines.value: but neither virginia nor other states observed the ruling and it was not enforced for decades
lines.name: English

lines.value: irene morgan was born in 1917 in baltimore maryland
lines.name: English

lines.value: she attended local schools and was raised as a seventh day adventist
lines.name: English

lines.value: morgan married sherwood morgan sr and had a son and daughter with him
lines.name: English

lines.value: he died in 1948
lines.name: English

lines.value: during world war ii she helped the war effort by working at glenn l martin an aircraft manufacturer and defense contractor in baltimore
lines.name: English

lines.value: she worked on the production line for the b 26 marauder
lines.name: English

lines.value: she later married stanley kirkaldy and moved with him to new york city
lines.name: English

lines.value: they ran a child care center near where they lived in queens
lines.name: English

lines.value: in her 60s kirkaldy started college studies attending st john's university in new york city she received her bachelor's degree when she was 68 years old
lines.name: English

lines.value: five years later morgan earned a master's degree in urban studies from queens college
lines.name: English

lines.value: irene morgan had been dealing with a recent miscarriage and was visiting her mother in gloucester county virginia to physically and mentally recover from the ordeal
lines.name: English

lines.value: hoping to go back home so she could continue working on the production line for the b 26 marauder irene morgan boarded a greyhound to return to baltimore maryland
lines.name: English

lines.value: on july 16 1944 morgan boarded the greyhound bus and had sat down next to another african american woman who was carrying an infant
lines.name: English

lines.value: an african american could not sit next to or across from a caucasian passenger but there were no designated black or white seats on the bus
lines.name: English

lines.value: when a white couple boarded the bus at a stop in middlesex county virginia the bus driver ordered morgan and her seatmate to surrender their seats
lines.name: English

lines.value: her seatmate immediately retreated to the back of the bus with her infant but morgan refused to give up her spot
lines.name: English

lines.value: when morgan would not move the bus driver hopped off the bus to grab a sheriff
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sheriff presented morgan with an arrest warrant but she tore up the piece of paper and threw it out of the window of the bus
lines.name: English

lines.value: when the sheriff touched her to pull her out of her seat she kicked him in the groin
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sheriff got off the bus and a different sheriff was sent on
lines.name: English

lines.value: he touched me that's when i kicked him in a very bad place
lines.name: English

lines.value: he hobbled off and another one came on
lines.name: English

lines.value: i was going to bite him but he looked dirty so i clawed him instead
lines.name: English

lines.value: i ripped his shirt
lines.name: English

lines.value: we were both pulling at each other
lines.name: English

lines.value: he said he would use his nightstick
lines.name: English

lines.value: i said we'll whip each other'"
lines.name: English

lines.value: the second sheriff got off the bus to grab the deputy
lines.name: English

lines.value: morgan was arrested
lines.name: English

lines.value: she had been charged with resisting arrest and violating virginia's jim crow transit law
lines.name: English

lines.value: on october 18th 1944 morgan attended her court case
lines.name: English

lines.value: she agreed to pay a $100 fine for resisting arrest but refused to plead to the segregation violation
lines.name: English

lines.value: since maryland did not enforce segregation for interstate travel virginias jim crow law could possibly not apply to morgan
lines.name: English

lines.value: morgan's case with the help of the naacp was taken to the virginia supreme court
lines.name: English

lines.value: the supreme court ruled her in violation of the law
lines.name: English

lines.value: morgan then took her case to the us supreme court and won
lines.name: English

lines.value: her case irene morgan v commonwealth of virginia was argued by william h hastie the former governor of the us virgin islands and later a judge on the us court of appeals for the third circuit
lines.name: English

lines.value: thurgood marshall of the naacp was co counsel
lines.name: English

lines.value: he later was appointed as a us supreme court justice
lines.name: English

lines.value: the us supreme court ruled 6-1 in 1946 that virginia's state law enforcing segregation on interstate buses was unconstitutional
lines.name: English

lines.value: hastie and marshall used an innovative strategy to brief and argue the case
lines.name: English

lines.value: instead of relying upon the equal protection clause of the 14th amendment they argued successfully that segregation on interstate travel violated the interstate commerce clause of the us constitution
lines.name: English

lines.value: if something happens to you which is wrong the best thing to do is have it corrected in the best way you can said morgan
lines.name: English

lines.value: the best thing for me to do was to go to the supreme court in 1960 in boynton v virginia the supreme court extended the morgan ruling to bus terminals used in interstate bus service
lines.name: English

lines.value: african americans continued to be ejected or arrested when they tried to integrate such facilities as southern states refused to obey morgan v virginia
lines.name: English

lines.value: they staged numerous non violent demonstrations using interstate buses and bus terminals such as the freedom rides of 1961
lines.name: English

lines.value: white southerners attacked the freedom riders attracting renewed national media attention to the south's jim crow system
lines.name: English

lines.value: morgan's case inspired the 1947 journey of reconciliation during which 16 activists from the chicago based congress of racial equality rode on interstate buses through the upper south to test the enforcement of the supreme court's ruling
lines.name: English

lines.value: the activists divided themselves between the interstate greyhound and trailways bus lines
lines.name: English

lines.value: they usually placed an interracial pair in the white area of the bus
lines.name: English

lines.value: other activists disguised as ordinary passengers rode in the racial sections reserved for them by segregation law
lines.name: English

lines.value: the group traveled uneventfully through virginia but when they reached north carolina they encountered arrests and violence
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the end of the journey the protesters had conducted over 24 tests and endured 12 arrests and dangerous mob violence
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a flagrant violation of the morgan decision north carolina police arrested the civil rights activist bayard rustin
lines.name: English

lines.value: a jury convicted him and he was sentenced to 22 days on a chain gang for violating the state's segregation laws although he had been riding on an interstate bus
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 1947 journey of reconciliation ahead of its time in the use of tactics of nonviolent direct action inspired the highly publicized freedom rides of 1961 also organized by core

lines.value: william mervine 14 march 1791 &ndash 15 september 1868 was a rear admiral in the united states navy whose career included service in the war of 1812 the mexican american war and the american civil war
lines.name: English

lines.value: born in philadelphia pennsylvania mervine was appointed midshipman in january 1809
lines.name: English

lines.value: serving on lake ontario during the war of 1812 he later cruised off africa and south america in the west indies and in the pacific
lines.name: English

lines.value: while in command of the during the war with mexico 1846–47 he led a detachment of sailors and united states marines against monterey california and on 7 july 1846 took possession and hoisted the american flag over the city
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 7 9 october 1846 mervine led 203 us marines 147 american sailors and volunteers in the invasion of los angeles where he lost the battle of dominguez rancho
lines.name: English

lines.value: fourteen marines were killed
lines.name: English

lines.value: jose antonio carrillo a californio rancher led 50 spanish californio lancers in that defeat of mervine and the american forces
lines.name: English

lines.value: serving also during the civil war he commanded the gulf blockading squadron from 6 may 1861 until obliged by ill health to give up the command on 22 september 1861
lines.name: English

lines.value: he died at utica new york
lines.name: English

lines.value: the navy has named two destroyers in his honor

lines.value: kenneth duane snelson june 29 1927 - december 22 2016 was an american contemporary sculptor and photographer
lines.name: English

lines.value: his sculptural works are composed of flexible and rigid components arranged according to the idea of tensegrity
lines.name: English

lines.value: snelson preferred the descriptive term floating compression
lines.name: English

lines.value: snelson said his former professor buckminster fuller took credit for snelson's discovery of the concept that fuller named tensegrity
lines.name: English

lines.value: fuller gave the idea its name combining tension and structural integrity the height and strength of snelson's sculptures which are often delicate in appearance depend on the tension between rigid pipes and flexible cables
lines.name: English

lines.value: snelson was born in pendleton oregon in 1927
lines.name: English

lines.value: he studied at the university of oregon in eugene at the black mountain college and with fernand leger in paris
lines.name: English

lines.value: his sculpture and photography have been exhibited at over 25 one man shows in galleries around the world including the structurally seminal park place gallery in new york in the 1960s
lines.name: English

lines.value: snelson also did research on the shape of the atom
lines.name: English

lines.value: snelson continued to work in his soho studio occasionally collaborating with animator jonathan monaghan
lines.name: English

lines.value: he lived in new york city with his wife katherine
lines.name: English

lines.value: he held five united states patents 3169611 discontinuous compression structures february 1965 3276148 model for atomic forms october 1966 4099339 model for atomic forms july 1978 and 6017220 magnetic geometric building system and most recently 6739937 space frame structure made by 3-d weaving of rod members may 25 2004
lines.name: English

lines.value: snelson was a founding member of construct the artist owned gallery that promoted and organized large scale sculpture exhibitions throughout the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: other founding members include mark di suvero john raymond henry lyman kipp and charles ginnever
lines.name: English

lines.value: after suffering from prostate cancer snelson died on december 22 2016 at the age of 89
lines.name: English

lines.value: in linear algebra a circulant matrix is a special kind of toeplitz matrix where each row vector is rotated one element to the right relative to the preceding row vector
lines.name: English

lines.value: in numerical analysis circulant matrices are important because they are diagonalized by a discrete fourier transform and hence linear equations that contain them may be quickly solved using a fast fourier transform
lines.name: English

lines.value: they can be interpreted analytically as the integral kernel of a convolution operator on the cyclic group which appears as the first column of
lines.name: English

lines.value: the normalized eigenvectors of a circulant matrix are given by
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a consequence of the explicit formula for the eigenvalues above the determinant of circulant matrix can be computed as
lines.name: English

lines.value: circulant matrices can be interpreted geometrically which explains the connection with the discrete fourier transform
lines.name: English

lines.value: consider vectors in this is a discrete circular convolution
lines.name: English

lines.value: the formula for the convolution of the functions is a circulant square matrix of size are cyclically extended in each direction
lines.name: English

lines.value: using the results of the [[discrete fourier transform#circular convolution theorem and cross correlation theorem|circular convolution theorem]] we can use the discrete fourier transform to transform the cyclic convolution into component wise multiplication this algorithm is much faster than the standard gaussian elimination especially if a fast fourier transform is used
lines.name: English

lines.value: in graph theory a graph or digraph whose adjacency matrix is circulant is called a circulant graph or digraph
lines.name: English

lines.value: equivalently a graph is circulant if its automorphism group contains a full length cycle
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mobius ladders are examples of circulant graphs as are the paley graphs for fields of prime order

lines.value: naked published in 1997 is a collection of essays by american humorist david sedaris
lines.name: English

lines.value: the book details sedaris life from his unusual upbringing in the suburbs of raleigh north carolina to his booze and drug ridden college years to his kerouacian wandering as a young adult
lines.name: English

lines.value: the book became a best seller and was acclaimed for its wit dark humor and irreverent tackling of tragic events including the death of sedaris mother
lines.name: English

lines.value: prior to publication several of the essays were read by the author on the public radio international program this american life
lines.name: English

lines.value: naked won the randy shilts award for gay non fiction from publishing triangle in 1998

lines.value: lennart nilsson 24 august 1922 &ndash 28 january 2017 was a swedish photographer and scientist
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was noted for his photographs of human embryos and other medical subjects once considered unphotographable and more generally for his extreme macro photography
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was also considered to be among sweden's first modern photojournalists
lines.name: English

lines.value: lennart nilsson was born in strangnas sweden
lines.name: English

lines.value: his father and uncle were both photographers
lines.name: English

lines.value: his father gave him his first camera at age twelve
lines.name: English

lines.value: when he was around fifteen he saw a documentary about louis pasteur that made him interested in microscopy
lines.name: English

lines.value: within a few years nilsson had acquired a microscope and was making microphotographs of insects
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his late teens and twenties he began taking a series of environmental portraits with an icoflex zeiss camera and had the opportunity to photograph many famous swedes
lines.name: English

lines.value: he began his professional career in the mid 1940s as a freelance photographer working frequently for the publisher ahlen & akerlund of stockholm
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of his earliest assignments was covering the liberation of norway in 1945 during world war ii
lines.name: English

lines.value: some of his early photo essays notably a midwife in lapland 1945 polar bear hunting in spitzbergen 1947 and fishermen at the congo river 1948 brought him international attention after publication in life illustrated picture post and elsewhere
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1954 eighty seven of his portraits of famous swedes were published in the book sweden in profile
lines.name: English

lines.value: his 1955 book reportage featured a selection of his early work
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1963 his photoessay about the swedish salvation army appeared in several magazines and in his book hallelujah
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the mid 1950s he began experimenting with new photographic techniques to make extreme close up photographs
lines.name: English

lines.value: these advances combined with very thin endoscopes that became available in the mid 1960s enabled him to make groundbreaking photographs of living human blood vessels and body cavities
lines.name: English

lines.value: he achieved international fame in 1965 when his photographs of the beginning of human life appeared on the cover and on sixteen pages of life magazine
lines.name: English

lines.value: they were also published in stern paris match the sunday times and elsewhere
lines.name: English

lines.value: the photographs made up a part of the book a child is born 1965 images from the book were reproduced in the april 30 1965 edition of life which sold eight million copies in the first four days after publication
lines.name: English

lines.value: some of the photographs from it were later included on both voyager spacecraft
lines.name: English

lines.value: in an interview published by pbs nilsson explained how he obtained photographs of living fetuses during medical procedures including laparoscopy and amniocentesis and discussed how he was able to light the inside of the mother's womb
lines.name: English

lines.value: describing a shoot that took place during a surgical procedure in goteborg he stated the fetus was moving not really sucking its thumb but it was moving and you could see everything heartbeats and umbilical cord and so on
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was extremely beautiful really beautiful nilsson also acknowledged obtaining human embryos from women's clinics in sweden
lines.name: English

lines.value: the university of cambridge claims that nilsson actually photographed abortus material working with dead embryos allowed nilsson to experiment with lighting background and positions such as placing the thumb into the fetus mouth
lines.name: English

lines.value: but the origin of the pictures was rarely mentioned even by anti abortion activists who in the 1970s appropriated these icons however nilsson himself has offered additional explanations for the sources of his photographs in other interviews stating that he at times used embryos that had been miscarried due to extra uterine or ectopic pregnancies
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1969 he began using a scanning electron microscope on a life assignment to depict the body's functions
lines.name: English

lines.value: he is generally credited with taking the first images of the human immunodeficiency virus and in 2003 he took the first image of the sars virus
lines.name: English

lines.value: around 1970 he joined the staff of the karolinska institutet
lines.name: English

lines.value: nilsson was also involved in the creation of documentaries including the saga of life 1982 and the miracle of life 1996
lines.name: English

lines.value: nilsson became a member of the swedish society of medicine in 1969 received an honorary doctorate in medicine from karolinska institute in 1976 an honorary doctor of philosophy from the technische universitat braunschweig in germany in 2002 and an honorary doctor of philosophy from linkoping university in sweden in 2003
lines.name: English

lines.value: he won the swedish academy nordic authors prize the first hasselblad foundation international award in photography in 1980 the royal swedish academy of engineering sciences big gold medal in 1989 and in 2002 received the 12th presentation of the swedish government's illis quorum
lines.name: English

lines.value: his documentaries won emmy awards in 1982 and 1996
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was award the royal photographic society's progress medal in 1993 in recognition of any invention research publication or other contribution which has resulted in an important advance in the scientific or technological development of photography nilsson's work is on exhibit in many locations including the british museum in london the tokyo fuji art museum and the modern museum in stockholm
lines.name: English

lines.value: since 1998 the lennart nilsson award has been presented annually during the karolinska institute's installation ceremony
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is given in recognition of extraordinary photography of science and is sponsored by the lennart nilsson foundation
lines.name: English

lines.value: abida parveen urdu عابدہ پروینborn 20 february 1954 is a sufi singer composer and musician
lines.name: English

lines.value: her singing and music has earned her many accolades and she has been dubbed as the queen of sufi music
lines.name: English

lines.value: she is also a painter and entrepreneur being a business woman from pakistan
lines.name: English

lines.value: born and raised in larkana into a sindhi sufi family she was trained by her father ghulam haider who was a famous singer and music teacher
lines.name: English

lines.value: she plays pump organ keyboard and sitar
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen started performing in early 1970s and came into global prominence in the 1990s
lines.name: English

lines.value: since 1993 parveen has toured globally performing her first international concert at buena park california
lines.name: English

lines.value: she had performed in churches also several times
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen also features in pakistan's popular musical show coke studio and was a judge on the pan south asia contest show sur kshetra alongside runa laila and asha bhosle hosted by ayesha takia
lines.name: English

lines.value: it also features atif aslam and himesh reshammiya
lines.name: English

lines.value: she had appeared in various indian and pakistani music reality shows including pakistan idol chhote ustaad and star voice of india
lines.name: English

lines.value: being the sufi sensation she is among the 500 most influential muslims of the world
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the power to induce hysteria in her audience parveen is a global mystic sufi ambassador
lines.name: English

lines.value: since last few years she sings a song for pepsi ad in the month of ramadan and also collaborated with atif aslam once in it.parveen is referred as one of the world's greatest mystic singers
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen is reportedly among highest paid singers in pakistan
lines.name: English

lines.value: she sings mainly ghazals thumri khyal qawwali raga raag sufi rock classical semi classical music and her forte kafis a solo genre accompanied by percussion and harmonium using a repertoire of songs by sufi poets
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen sings in urdu sindhi saraiki punjabi arabic and persian
lines.name: English

lines.value: she had also sung a famous song in nepali language called ukali orali haruma by nepali singer tara devi in a concert in kathmandu nepal which was attended by govinda
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2017 she was designated a peace ambassador by saarc
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen is best known for her songs in bloomy loud voice yaar ko humne from the album raqs e bismil and tere ishq nachaya which is a rendition of bulleh shah's poetry
lines.name: English

lines.value: pakistan's second highest civilian award the hilal e imtiaz has been bestowed upon her by the president of pakistan for 2012
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen was born in mohalla ali goharabad in larkana sindh pakistan
lines.name: English

lines.value: she received her musical training initially from her father ustad ghulam haider whom she refers as baba sain and gawwaya
lines.name: English

lines.value: he had his own musical school where parveen got her devotional inspiration from
lines.name: English

lines.value: she and her father would often perform at shrines of sufi saints
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen's talent compelled her father to choose her as his musical heir over his two sons
lines.name: English

lines.value: growing up she attended her father's music school where her foundation in music was laid
lines.name: English

lines.value: later ustad salamat ali khan of the sham chaurasia gharana also taught and nurtured her
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen always remembers that she was never forced towards this occupation and she sang her first complete kalam when she was only 3 years old
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen had already begun performing at dargahs and urs in the early 1970s but it was in 1973 on radio pakistan that that she achieved her first real breakthrough with the sindhi song tuhinje zulfan jay band kamand widha
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1977 she was introduced as an official singer on radio pakistan
lines.name: English

lines.value: since then parveen has risen to prominence and is now considered one of the finest vocal artists of pakistan
lines.name: English

lines.value: she has imbued sufi music with a new identity marking the beginning of this journey at sultana siddiqui's awazoandaz in 1980
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen travels internationally often performing at sold out venues
lines.name: English

lines.value: her 1988 performance in chicago was recorded by the hazrat amir khusrau society of art and culture which issued a lp of her songs
lines.name: English

lines.value: her 1989 performance in london's wembley conference centre was broadcast on the bbc
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen cites her motivation for international travel as being to spread sufism peace and the divine message
lines.name: English

lines.value: in doing so she also promotes pakistani culture
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1990s parveen licensed her spiritual ghazals to bollywood since her spiritual brother khan recorded songs for bollywood
lines.name: English

lines.value: recently abida also performed at the grand finale of sindh festival by bilawal bhutto zardari in thatta
lines.name: English

lines.value: parveen began performing on the internationally acclaimed pakistani show coke studio in 2010
lines.name: English

lines.value: the music that comes out of this project reaches both the heart and soul and it always compliments the lyrics without overriding the true message of the kalams

lines.value: this platform builds on those messages of our sufi elders she was invited back in season 7 in 2014

lines.value: in 1975 abida married ghulam hussain sheikh senior producer at radio pakistan who had retired from his job in the 1980s to manage and mentor parveen's career

lines.value: after he died of a heart attack on an international flight in the early 2000s their daughter maryam took up that role

lines.value: norma precision is a swedish manufacturer of ammunition located in amotfors in the province of varmland just 20 km off the norwegian border
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is commonly referred to as simply norma
lines.name: English

lines.value: norma was started in 1902 by the enger brothers from oslo who a few years earlier started norma projektilfabrik a/s
lines.name: English

lines.value: the name norma has contrary to what someone would think nothing to do with norwegian or normandy
lines.name: English

lines.value: the name was chosen because one of the enger brothers was very fond of the opera norma by bellini
lines.name: English

lines.value: the swedish shooting movement needed a swedish supplier and norma projektilfabrik a/s was asked to establish in sweden
lines.name: English

lines.value: at this time sweden and norway were in a union
lines.name: English

lines.value: the enger brothers took the train to sweden and simply got off at the first stop on the other side of the border charlottenberg and made inquiries about a suitable factory building
lines.name: English

lines.value: however they found the town council took no interest in their plans and therefore decided to try their luck further into sweden
lines.name: English

lines.value: next stop was amotfors where the brothers were better welcomed and decided to establish their company
lines.name: English

lines.value: from the start until the middle of the century the production was dominated by military ammunition standards
lines.name: English

lines.value: after a while though hunting ammunition seemed to be more interesting
lines.name: English

lines.value: norma began to make international connections by this time
lines.name: English

lines.value: this combined with military interest forced more modern thinking and new products which the company pursued with impressive precision
lines.name: English

lines.value: nils kvale and roy weatherby were invaluable for norma's success in the latter half of the 20th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: nils kvale was a visionary and competent product developer
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1960s a couple of new calibers like the .308 norma magnum and .358 norma magnum were introduced on the market
lines.name: English

lines.value: nils kvale's cooperation with american colleagues made norma well known as a producer of high quality rifle ammunition
lines.name: English

lines.value: today norma has a yearly production of about 30 million rounds in 110 calibers
lines.name: English

lines.value: as such norma has one of the largest assortments of rifle ammunition in the world
lines.name: English

lines.value: a ballroom or ballhall is a large room inside a building the designated purpose of which is holding large formal parties called balls
lines.name: English

lines.value: traditionally most balls were held in private residences many mansions contain one or more ballrooms
lines.name: English

lines.value: in other large houses a large room such as the main drawing room long gallery or hall may double as a ballroom but a good ballroom should have the right type of flooring such as hardwood flooring or stone flooring usually marble
lines.name: English

lines.value: in later times the term ballroom has been used to describe nightclubs where punters dance the top rank suites in the united kingdom for example were also often referred to as ballrooms
lines.name: English

lines.value: the phrase having a ball has grown to encompass many events where person(s are having fun not just dancing
lines.name: English

lines.value: ballrooms are generally quite large and may have ceilings higher than other rooms in the same building
lines.name: English

lines.value: the large amount of space for dancing as well as the highly formal tone of events have given rise to ballroom dancing
lines.name: English

lines.value: the largest balls are now nearly always held in public buildings and many hotels have a ballroom
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are also designed large to help the sound of orchestras carry well throughout the whole room
lines.name: English

lines.value: a special case is the annual vienna opera ball where just for one night the auditorium of the vienna state opera is turned into a large ballroom
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the eve of the event the rows of seats are removed from the stalls and a new floor level with the stage is built
lines.name: English

lines.value: sometimes ballrooms have stages in the front of the room where the host or a special guest can speak
lines.name: English

lines.value: that stage can also be used for instrumentalists and musical performers
lines.name: English

lines.value: these lists should only include ballrooms with permanent wood floors
lines.name: English

lines.value: the size of the floor should only include the largest contiguous area without obstructions
lines.name: English

lines.value: the web sites and materials about some places add up multiple spaces rooms and balconies and floors
lines.name: English

lines.value: however this list ranks ballrooms based on the size of one single open space with a hardwood floor
lines.name: English
