lines.value: robert burnell sometimes spelled robert burnel c 1239 - 25 october 1292 was an english bishop who served as lord chancellor of england from 1274 to 1292
lines.name: English

lines.value: a native of shropshire he served as a minor royal official before entering into the service of prince edward the future king edward i of england
lines.name: English

lines.value: when edward went on the eighth crusade in 1270 burnell stayed in england to secure the prince's interests
lines.name: English

lines.value: he served as regent after the death of king henry iii of england while edward was still on crusade
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was twice elected archbishop of canterbury but his personal life which included a long term mistress who was rumoured to have borne him four sons prevented his confirmation by the papacy
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1275 burnell was elected bishop of bath and wells after edward had appointed him lord chancellor in 1274
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell was behind the efforts of the royal officials to enforce royal rights during his term of office as chancellor including the implementation of the quo warranto procedures
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also helped with the legislative and legal reforms of edward's reign
lines.name: English

lines.value: during burnell's tenure the chancellor's office and records became fixed in london rather than travelling with the king
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell went abroad on diplomatic missions for edward and for a time governed gascony
lines.name: English

lines.value: he continued to enjoy the king's trust until his death in 1292 one historian has suggested that burnell may have been the most important royal official of the 13th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1198 burnell's family had bestowed its name on the village of acton burnell in shropshire where burnell was born probably in about 1239 as he was close in age to king edward
lines.name: English

lines.value: his father was probably roger burnell who died in about 1259
lines.name: English

lines.value: he had three brothers two of whom died fighting the welsh at the battle of moel y don in 1282 the third hugh died in 1286
lines.name: English

lines.value: hugh's son philip was robert's eventual heir
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell worked as a clerk in the royal chancery the office responsible for the writing of documents before moving to the household of prince edward later king edward i of england
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1257 burnell was spending most of his time with the prince and the prince's household
lines.name: English

lines.value: after simon de montfort's victory at the battle of lewes in 1264 burnell continued to serve edward and was named the prince's clerk in december 1264
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a reward for his service burnell was given the prebend of holme in the diocese of york some time before 1267 and was named archdeacon of york in december 1270
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also held the office of chancellor to edward from the time of the battle of evesham in 1265 until 1270 when edward left on crusade
lines.name: English

lines.value: prince edward tried to have burnell elected to the archbishopric of canterbury in 1270 but was frustrated by the canterbury cathedral chapter's members who instead elected their prior william chillenden
lines.name: English

lines.value: eventually pope gregory x set chillenden aside and installed his own choice in the see robert kilwardby
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell did not accompany the prince on crusade in late 1270 although he had originally planned to do so
lines.name: English

lines.value: instead he was appointed one of the four lieutenants who looked after edward's interests while the prince was away
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus he was still in england when henry iii died in november 1272
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell acted as one of the regents of the kingdom until august 1274 when the prince now king returned from palestine
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the regency burnell supervised a parliament dealt with raids on the welsh marches and resolved a trade conflict with flanders
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the king's return to england burnell was made chancellor
lines.name: English

lines.value: the historian richard huscroft considers that burnell gained valuable experience governing england during edward's absence ensuring burnell's dominance in the english government after edward's return
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 23 january 1275 burnell was elected to the see of bath and wells
lines.name: English

lines.value: he received the temporalities of the see on 19 march 1275 and was consecrated on 7 april 1275
lines.name: English

lines.value: three years later edward once more tried to secure the see of canterbury for his favourite
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell was elected to the archbishopric in june or july 1278 but the election was quashed by pope nicholas iii in january 1279
lines.name: English

lines.value: king edward sent a deputation including the eventual appointee john peckham to secure nicholas confirmation of the election
lines.name: English

lines.value: the pope named three cardinals as investigators and then appointed peckham instead
lines.name: English

lines.value: the bishop's second failure to obtain the archbishopric was probably a consequence of his lifestyle which included keeping a mistress
lines.name: English

lines.value: edward made one final attempt to promote his friend to a wealthier see in early 1280 when burnell was nominated to become bishop of winchester but pope nicholas iii quashed the election on 28 june 1280
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell was the chief and most influential of edward i's advisers during the first half of his reign
lines.name: English

lines.value: as part of his duties burnell spent most of his time in attendance on the king
lines.name: English

lines.value: he heard many requests and petitions from those who desired patronage or other advancements and was diligent and active in dealing with routine business
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell played a leading role in the legislation introduced by king edward
lines.name: English

lines.value: the king's major legislative acts mainly date to burnell's tenure of the office of chancellor from 21 september 1274 until burnell's death in 1292
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell was instrumental in the enforcement of royal writs and enactments including the statutes of westminster enacted in 1275 1285 and 1290
lines.name: English

lines.value: those of 1275 attempted to deal with the usurpation of royal rights
lines.name: English

lines.value: keeping the peace in the realm and the extension of royal jurisdiction to cover rape was dealt with in the statutes from 1285 along with a number of other issues
lines.name: English

lines.value: the last statute from 1290 regulated land law the result of pressure from the magnates the leading laymen of england
lines.name: English

lines.value: during burnell's time in office edward and his royal officials made great efforts to reassert royal rights that were felt to have been usurped by the king's subjects
lines.name: English

lines.value: these efforts were made under writs of quo warranto which asked the recipient what royal grant or warrant gives the recipient the authority to exercise a right or a power
lines.name: English

lines.value: they were first issued in 1278 after earlier attempts to recover royal rights through parliament unintentionally resulted in too much work for that body
lines.name: English

lines.value: through these writs attempts were made to enforce the rule that the only correct way to receive a privilege or grant of land was through a written charter which might have deprived most of the magnates of england of their lands and rights
lines.name: English

lines.value: most lands at that time were held not by documentary grants but by the force of custom
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the 1290s the government was forced to back down and permit rights as they had been allowed from time out of mind
lines.name: English

lines.value: the distinction between the king's personal household department of the wardrobe and the governmental department of the chancery which was headed by the chancellor disappeared almost entirely during burnell's period of office
lines.name: English

lines.value: the wardrobe had developed as a less formal department for the collection and distribution of money but under edward had effectively become a treasury for warfare
lines.name: English

lines.value: there was no rivalry between the holders of the great seal the official seal of government and used for formal documents and the privy seal used to authenticate the king's less formal letters
lines.name: English

lines.value: during burnell's time in office the king only used a privy seal warrant or an informal set of instructions for the chancellor to issue a letter from the chancery under the great seal when the king and burnell were apart after burnell's death the number of privy seal warrants increased greatly
lines.name: English

lines.value: edward had such trust in his chancellor and the chancellor's clerks that burnell and the clerks were allowed to dispense with the hanaper system which required fees for sealing charters to be paid into the hanaper department of the chancery for disbursal
lines.name: English

lines.value: robert and his clerks were permitted to enjoy the profits from the fees of their office
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell was also responsible for the decision to force the court of chancery to settle in london rather than following the king and his court around the country
lines.name: English

lines.value: a chancery memorandum of 1280 records that the chancellor along with the other ministers now had the duty of sorting the many petitions that came into the government and only passing on the most urgent to the king
lines.name: English

lines.value: as bishop burnell had a wall built around the cathedral at wells which helped to improve the security of the cathedral and its outlying buildings
lines.name: English

lines.value: he left the court each year at lent when he returned to his diocese and attended to its affairs
lines.name: English

lines.value: peckham appointed burnell to be his deputy when the archbishop went to wales in 1282
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was probably burnell who suggested a compromise in 1285 over the jurisdictions of the royal and ecclesiastical courts which allowed royal officials to return cases involving only religious matters to the church courts
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell was active in the king's foreign policy especially towards france scotland and wales and undertook a number of diplomatic missions to those countries
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell served as the royal spokesman on several of these occasions one of them being at paris in 1286 when he made a speech detailing the history of english french relations since the treaty of paris of 1259
lines.name: English

lines.value: the speech was a prelude to discussions successfully concluded involving the homage that edward owed to king philip iv of france for edward's land in france
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell was employed in gascony during the late 1280s helping to administer that duchy and to reorganise its government
lines.name: English

lines.value: he showed himself sensitive to the gascon desire for independence and did not attempt to impose the same systems of government that were used in england
lines.name: English

lines.value: the historian michael prestwich therefore argues that the first half of edward's reign was the period when gascony enjoyed its most successful government under the plantagenets
lines.name: English

lines.value: later in june 1291 burnell gave two speeches at the great council of english and scottish nobles in norham to decide the succession to the scottish crown
lines.name: English

lines.value: edward had been asked to mediate an end to the crisis over the succession or the great cause as it was known in england
lines.name: English

lines.value: in welsh affairs burnell attended a number of councils dealing with llywelyn ap gruffudd prince of wales and in 1277 he escorted llywelyn to westminster where llywelyn pledged homage to edward
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell was present during edward's conquest of wales in the 1280s he witnessed documents in rhuddlan in 1282 and subsequently at conwy and caernarfon
lines.name: English

lines.value: sometime before 1290 burnell vowed to go on crusade to help reinforce the crusader city of acre which was threatened by muslims in the late 1280s but he never fulfilled his obligation
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell died in berwick on 25 october 1292
lines.name: English

lines.value: his body without his heart is interred in the nave of wells cathedral his heart was buried at bath abbey
lines.name: English

lines.value: although he was usually busy with royal business burnell managed to expand his bishopric and provide for his relatives
lines.name: English

lines.value: he amassed great wealth and acquired numerous estates in shropshire worcestershire somerset kent surrey and elsewhere
lines.name: English

lines.value: at his death he owned 82 manors over 19 counties most of them his personal property rather than that of the diocese of bath and wells
lines.name: English

lines.value: even after he became a bishop burnell kept a mistress juliana
lines.name: English

lines.value: rumours circulated that she bore him four sons and that he had a number of daughters all of which burnell denied
lines.name: English

lines.value: he kept a magnificent household sufficient for him to be able to host a parliament at his home in acton burnell in autumn 1283
lines.name: English

lines.value: he married off a number of young female relatives rumoured to be his daughters to noblemen
lines.name: English

lines.value: amabilla burnell married a member of a royal justice's family and a joan burnell was the subject of a guarantee to the bishop that the son of william of greystoke would marry her
lines.name: English

lines.value: a william burnell was dean of wells cathedral and was named as one of the bishop's executors
lines.name: English

lines.value: robert burnell's eventual heir was his nephew philip
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell built extensively at acton burnell castle and large parts of his house have survived
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was substantially different in plan from the older hall style houses which had the private quarters at the back of a large hall
lines.name: English

lines.value: at acton burnell the bishop's quarters were well away from the building's main public spaces and included a latrine
lines.name: English

lines.value: the house was not quite a castle but it was designed to have some defensive capability
lines.name: English

lines.value: the overall form of the structure was of a fortified hall house much like the norman era hall keeps
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also built the chapel and great hall in the bishop's palace in wells
lines.name: English

lines.value: burnell was a dominant figure during the first part of edward's reign and he controlled most aspects of royal administration
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was involved not only in domestic issues but also in foreign relations a responsibility he retained for two decades after edward's return to england in 1274
lines.name: English

lines.value: huscroft argues that he may have been the most important royal administrator of the 13th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: * inquisition post mortem at british history online
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is item number 65 on the list
lines.name: English

lines.value: groenlinks (;, , gl is a green political party in the netherlands
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party was formed on 1 march 1989 from the merger of four left wing parties the communist party of the netherlands the pacifist socialist party the political party of radicals and the evangelical people's party
lines.name: English

lines.value: after disappointing results in the 1989 and 1994 general elections the nascent party fared particularly well in the elections that took place between 1994 and 2002
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party's leader at that time paul rosenmoller was seen as the unofficial leader of the opposition against the first kok cabinet a purple government
lines.name: English

lines.value: groenlinks describes itself as green social and tolerant
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party holds 14 seats in the house of representatives 5 in the senate and 2 in the european parliament
lines.name: English

lines.value: the current leader of groenlinks and chair of the house parliamentary group is jesse klaver
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party is in opposition against the governing third rutte cabinet
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party has over 100 local councillors and it participates in the government of sixteen of the twenty largest municipalities
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party's voters are concentrated in larger cities especially those with a university
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party has 21901 members which are organised in over 250 municipal branches
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party congress is open to all members
lines.name: English

lines.value: groenlinks is a member of the global greens and the european green party
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party's number of seats fell from 10 to 4 seats in the 2012 election before increasing to 14 in the 2017 general election
lines.name: English

lines.value: groenlinks was founded in 1989 as a merger of four parties that were to the left of the labour party pvda a social democratic party which has traditionally been the largest centre left party in the netherlands
lines.name: English

lines.value: the founding parties were the destalinised communist party of the netherlands cpn the pacifist socialist party psp which originated in the peace movement the green influenced political party of radicals ppr originally a progressive christian party and the progressive christian evangelical people's party
lines.name: English

lines.value: these four parties were frequently classified as small left to indicate their marginal existence
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1972 general election these parties won sixteen seats out of 150 in the 1977 general election they only won six
lines.name: English

lines.value: from that moment on members and voters began to argue for close cooperation
lines.name: English

lines.value: from the 1980s onwards the four parties started to cooperate in municipal and provincial elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: as fewer seats are available in these representations a higher percentage of votes is required to gain a seat
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1984 european election the ppr cpn and psp formed the green progressive accord that entered as one into the european elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: they gained one seat which rotated between the psp and ppr
lines.name: English

lines.value: party members of the four parties also encountered each other in grassroots extraparliamentary protest against nuclear energy and nuclear weapons
lines.name: English

lines.value: more than 80% of the members of the psp cpn and ppr attended at least one of the two mass protests against the placement of nuclear weapons which took place in 1981 and 1983
lines.name: English

lines.value: the evangelical people's party was a relatively new party founded in 1981 as a splinter group from the christian democratic appeal the largest party of the dutch centre right
lines.name: English

lines.value: during its period in parliament 1982 1986 it had trouble positioning itself between the small left parties psp ppr and cpn the pvda and the cda
lines.name: English

lines.value: the increasingly close cooperation between ppr psp cpn and evp and the ideological change that accompanied it was not without internal dissent within the parties
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ideological change that cpn made from official communism to reformism led to a split in the cpn and the subsequent founding of the league of communists in the netherlands in 1982
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1983 a group of deep greens split from the ppr to found the greens
lines.name: English

lines.value: the cpn and the ppr wanted to form an electoral alliance with the psp for the 1986 elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: this led to a crisis within the psp in which chair of the parliamentary party fractievoorzitter fred van der spek who opposed cooperation was replaced by andree van es who favoured cooperation
lines.name: English

lines.value: van der spek left the psp to found his own party for socialism and disarmament
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 1986 psp congress however rejected the electoral alliance
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1986 general election all four parties lost seats
lines.name: English

lines.value: the cpn and the evp disappeared from parliament
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ppr was left with two and the psp with one seat
lines.name: English

lines.value: while the parties were preparing to enter in the 1990 elections separately the pressure to cooperate increased
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1989 the ppr cpn and psp entered the 1989 european parliament election with a single list called the rainbow
lines.name: English

lines.value: joost lagendijk and leo platvoet both psp party board members initiated an internal referendum in which the members of the psp declared to support leftwing cooperation 70% in favour 64% of all members voting
lines.name: English

lines.value: their initiative for left wing cooperation was supported by an open letter from influential members of trade unions such as paul rosenmoller and karin adelmund of environmental movements e.g jacqueline cramer and from arts such as rudi van dantzig
lines.name: English

lines.value: this letter called for the formation of a single progressive party to the left of the labour party
lines.name: English

lines.value: lagendijk and platvoet had been taking part in informal meetings between prominent psp ppr and cpn members who favoured cooperation
lines.name: English

lines.value: other participants were ppr chairman bram van ojik and former cpn leader ina brouwer
lines.name: English

lines.value: these talks were called fc sittardia or cliche bv
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the spring of 1989 the psp party board initiated formal talks between the cpn the psp and the ppr about a common list for the upcoming general elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: it soon became clear that the cpn wanted to maintain an independent communist identity and not merge into a new left wing formation
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was reason for the ppr leaving the talks
lines.name: English

lines.value: negotiations about cooperation were reopened after the fall of the second lubbers cabinet and the announcement that elections would be held in the autumn of that year
lines.name: English

lines.value: this time the evp was included in the discussion
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ppr was represented for a short while by an informal delegation led by former chair wim de boer because the party board did not want to be seen reentering the negotiations it had left only a short while earlier
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the summer of 1989 the party congresses of all four parties accepted to enter the elections with a shared programme and list of candidates
lines.name: English

lines.value: additionally the association greenleft dutch vereniging groenlinks vgl was set up to allow sympathisers not member of any of the four parties to join
lines.name: English

lines.value: meanwhile the european elections of 1989 were held in which the same group of parties had entered as a single list under the name rainbow
lines.name: English

lines.value: in practice the merger of the parties had now happened and the party greenleft was officially founded on 24 november 1990
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1989 elections the ppr psp cpn and evp entered in the elections with one single list called groen links
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the netherlands parties usually participate in the elections with one list for the whole country
lines.name: English

lines.value: the candidates on top of the list get the priority for the distribution of seats won
lines.name: English

lines.value: the greenleft list of candidates was organised in such a way that all the parties were represented and new figures could enter
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ppr which had been the largest party in 1986 got the top candidate the lijsttrekker ria beckers and the number five the psp got the numbers two and six the cpn the number three and the evp number eleven
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first independent candidate was paul rosenmoller trade unionist from rotterdam on the fourth place
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the elections the party doubled its seats in comparison to 1986 from three to six but the expectations had been much higher
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1990 municipal elections the party fared much better strengthening the resolve to cooperate
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the period 1989 1991 the merger developed further
lines.name: English

lines.value: a board was organised for the party in foundation and also a greenleft council which was supposed to control the board and the parliamentary party and stimulate the process of merger
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this council all five groups - cpn ppr psp evp and the vereniging groen links - had seats on ratio of the number of their members
lines.name: English

lines.value: originally the three youth organisations the cpn linked general dutch youth league the psp linked pacifist socialist young working groups and the ppr linked political party of radical youth refused to merge but under pressure of the government who controlled their subsidies they did merge to form dwars
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1990 some opposition formed against the moderate green course of greenleft
lines.name: English

lines.value: several former psp members united in the left forum in 1992 - they would leave the party to join former psp leader van der spek to found the psp'92
lines.name: English

lines.value: similarly former members of the cpn joined the league of communists in the netherlands to found the new communist party in the same year
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1991 the congresses of the four founding parties psp ppr cpn and evp decided to officially abolish their parties
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft had considerable problems formulating its own ideology
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1990 the attempt to write the first manifesto of principles failed because of the difference between socialists and communists on the one side and the more liberal former ppr members on the other side
lines.name: English

lines.value: the second manifesto of principles - which was not allowed to be called that - was adopted after a lengthy debate and many amendments in 1991
lines.name: English

lines.value: although the party was internally divided the greenleft parliamentary party was the only party in the dutch parliament which opposed the gulf war
lines.name: English

lines.value: a debate within the party about the role military intervention led to a more nuanced standpoint than the pacifism of some of its predecessors greenleft would support peace keeping missions as long as they were mandated by the united nations
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the fall of 1990 mep verbeek announced that he would not as he had promised leave the european parliament after two and a half years to make room for a new candidate
lines.name: English

lines.value: he would continue as an independent and remain in parliament until 1994
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1994 european elections he would run unsuccessfully as top candidate of the greens
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1992 party leader ria beckers left the house of representatives because she wanted more private time
lines.name: English

lines.value: peter lankhorst replaced her as chair ad interim but he announced that he would not take part in the internal elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: before the general election of 1994 greenleft organised an internal election on the party's political leadership
lines.name: English

lines.value: two duos entered ina brouwer former cpn combined with mohammed rabbae independent while paul rosenmoller independent formed a combination with leoni sipkes former psp there were also five individual candidates including wim de boer former chair of the ppr and member of the senate herman meijer former cpn future chair of the party and ineke van gent former psp and future mp
lines.name: English

lines.value: some candidates ran in duos because they wanted to combine family life with politics
lines.name: English

lines.value: brouwer rosenmoller and sipkes already were mps for greenleft whilst rabbae was new - he had been chair of the dutch centre for foreigners
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the first round the duos ended up ahead of the others but neither had an absolute majority
lines.name: English

lines.value: a second round was needed in which brouwer and rabbae won with 51%
lines.name: English

lines.value: brouwer became the first candidate and rabbae second the second duo rosenmoller and sipkes occupied the following place followed by marijke vos former chair of the party
lines.name: English

lines.value: the idea of a dual top candidacy did not communicate well to the voters
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft lost one seat leaving only five
lines.name: English

lines.value: yet in the same election the centre left labour party also lost a lot of seats
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the disappointing elections brouwer left parliament
lines.name: English

lines.value: she was replaced as party leader by paul rosenmoller and her seat was taken by tara singh varma
lines.name: English

lines.value: the charismatic rosenmoller became the unofficial leader of the opposition against the first kok cabinet because the largest opposition party the christian democratic appeal was unable to adapt well to its new role as opposition party
lines.name: English

lines.value: rosenmoller set out a new strategy greenleft should offer alternatives instead of only rejecting the proposals made by the government
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1998 general election greenleft more than doubled its seats to eleven
lines.name: English

lines.value: the charisma of unofficial leader rosenmoller played an important role in this
lines.name: English

lines.value: many new faces entered parliament including femke halsema a political talent who had left the labour party for greenleft in 1997
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party began to speculate openly about joining government after the elections of 2002
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 1999 kosovo war divided the party internally
lines.name: English

lines.value: the parliamentary party in the house of representatives supported the nato intervention while the senate parliamentary party was against the intervention
lines.name: English

lines.value: several former psp members within the house of representatives parliamentary party began to openly speak out their doubts about the intervention
lines.name: English

lines.value: a compromise was found greenleft would support the intervention as long as it limited itself to military targets
lines.name: English

lines.value: prominent members of the founding parties including marcus bakker en joop vogt left the party over this issue
lines.name: English

lines.value: in february 2001 roel van duijn and a few former members of the greens joined greenleft
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2001 the integrity of former mp tara singh varma came into doubt it was revealed that she had lied about her illness and that she had made promises to development organisations which she did not fulfill
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2000 she had left parliament because as she claimed she had only a few months to live before she would die of cancer
lines.name: English

lines.value: the tros program opgelicht in english framed revealed that she had lied and that she did not have cancer
lines.name: English

lines.value: later she apologised on public television and claimed she suffered from post traumatic stress disorder
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the same year the parliamentary party supported the invasion of afghanistan after the terrorist attacks of september 11
lines.name: English

lines.value: this invasion led to great upheaval within the party
lines.name: English

lines.value: several former psp members within the house of representatives parliamentary party began to openly speak out their doubts about the intervention
lines.name: English

lines.value: under pressure of internal opposition led by former psp members and the party's youth organisation dwars the parliamentary party changed its position the attacks should be cancelled
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 2002 general election was characterised by changes in the political climate
lines.name: English

lines.value: the right wing populist political commentator pim fortuyn entered into politics
lines.name: English

lines.value: he had an anti establishment message combined with a call for restrictions on immigration
lines.name: English

lines.value: although his critique was oriented at the second kok cabinet rosenmoller was one of the few politicians who could muster some resistance against his message
lines.name: English

lines.value: days before the election fortuyn was assassinated
lines.name: English

lines.value: ab harrewijn groenlinks mp and candidate also died
lines.name: English

lines.value: before and after the elections serious threats were made against rosenmoller his wife and his children
lines.name: English

lines.value: these events caused considerable stress for rosenmoller
lines.name: English

lines.value: groenlinks lost one seat in the election although it had gained more votes than in the 1998 elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: before the 2003 general election rosenmoller left parliament citing the ongoing threats against his life and those of his family as the main reason
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was replaced as chair of the parliamentary party and top candidate by femke halsema
lines.name: English

lines.value: she was unable to keep ten seats and lost two
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2003 greenleft almost unanimously turned against the iraq war
lines.name: English

lines.value: it took part in the protests against the war for instance by organising its party congress in amsterdam at the day of the large demonstration with an interval allowing its members to join the protest
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the end of 2003 halsema temporarily left parliament to give birth to her twins
lines.name: English

lines.value: during her absence marijke vos took her place as chair of the parliamentary party
lines.name: English

lines.value: when she returned to parliament halsema started a discussion about the principles of her party
lines.name: English

lines.value: she emphasised individual freedom tolerance self realisation and emancipation
lines.name: English

lines.value: in one interview she called her party the last liberal party of the netherlands this led to considerable attention of media and other observers which speculated about an ideological change
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2005 the party's scientific bureau published the book vrijheid als ideaal freedom as ideal in which prominent opinion makers explored the new political space and the position of the left within that space
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the congress of february 2007 the party board was ordered to organise a party wide discussion about the party's principles
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the european elections congress of 2004 the candidacy committee proposed that the chair of the greenleft delegation joost lagendijk should become the party's top candidate in those elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: a group of members led by senator leo platvoet submitted a motion we want to choose
lines.name: English

lines.value: they wanted a serious choice for such an important office
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party's board announced a new electoral procedure
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the congress kathalijne buitenweg an mep and candidate announced wish to be considered for the position of top candidate
lines.name: English

lines.value: she narrowly won the elections from lagendijk
lines.name: English

lines.value: this came as a great surprise to all
lines.name: English

lines.value: especially for buitenweg who had not written an acceptance speech and read out lagendijk's
lines.name: English

lines.value: in may 2005 mp farah karimi wrote a book in which discussed in detail how she had taken part in the iranian revolution because this information was already known by the party board this did not lead to any upheaval
lines.name: English

lines.value: in november 2005 the party board asked senator sam pormes to give up his seat
lines.name: English

lines.value: continuing rumours about his involvement with guerrilla training in yemen in the 1970s and the 1977 train hijacking by moluccan youth and allegations of welfare fraud were harmful for the party or at least so the party board claimed
lines.name: English

lines.value: when pormes refused to step down the party board threatened to expel him
lines.name: English

lines.value: pormes fought this decision
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party council of march 2006 sided with pormes
lines.name: English

lines.value: party chair herman meijer felt forced to resign
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was succeeded by henk nijhof who was chose by the party council in may 2006
lines.name: English

lines.value: in november 2006 pormes left the senate he was replaced by goos minderman
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 2006 dutch municipal election the party stayed relatively stable losing only a few seats
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the elections greenleft took part in 75 local executives including amsterdam where mp marijke vos became an alderwoman
lines.name: English

lines.value: in preparation of the 2006 general election the party held a congress in october
lines.name: English

lines.value: it elected halsema again the only candidate as the party's top candidate
lines.name: English

lines.value: mep kathalijne buitenweg and comedian vincent bijlo were last candidates
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 2006 elections the party lost one seat
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the subsequent cabinet formation an initial exploratory round among the christian democratic appeal cda labour party pvda and socialist party sp failed halsema announced that greenleft would not be involved in further discussion at that point in time as the party lost was too small and had less in common with cda than the sp had
lines.name: English

lines.value: following this decision an internal debate about the political course and the leadership of halsema reerupted
lines.name: English

lines.value: the debate does not just concern the series of lost elections and the decision not to participate in the formation talks but also the elitist image of the party the new liberal course initiated by halsema and the lack of party democracy
lines.name: English

lines.value: since the last weeks of january 2007 several prominent party members have voiced their doubts including former leader ina brouwer senator leo platvoet and mep joost lagendijk
lines.name: English

lines.value: in reaction to this the party board has set up a commission led by former mp and chair of the ppr bram van ojik
lines.name: English

lines.value: they looked into the lost series of elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the summer of 2007 another committee was formed to organise a larger debate about the course of the party's principles organisation and strategy
lines.name: English

lines.value: van ojik also led this committee
lines.name: English

lines.value: the committee implemented a motion already adopted by the party's congress in 2006 to reevaluate the party's principle in light of the party's course started by halsema ion 2004
lines.name: English

lines.value: over the course of 2007 and 2008 the committee organised an internal debate about the party's principles organisation and strategy
lines.name: English

lines.value: in november 2008 this led to the adoption of a new manifesto of principles
lines.name: English

lines.value: in august 2008 greenleft parliamentarian wijnand duyvendak published a book in which he admitted to a burglary of the ministry of economic affairs in order to steal plans for nuclear power plants
lines.name: English

lines.value: this led to his resignation on august 14 after media reported that the burglary also led to threats against civil servants
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was replaced by jolande sap
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2008 meps joost lagendijk and kathalijne buitenweg announced that they would not seek a new term in the european parliament
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party had to elect a new top candidate for the 2009 european elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: there were five candidates for this position amsterdam city councillor judith sargentini former mep alexander de roo senator tineke strik environmental researcher bas eickhout and niels van den berge assistant of mep buitenweg
lines.name: English

lines.value: in an internal referendum sargentini was elected
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party congress put eickhout on a second position on the list
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 18 april 2010 the party congress composed the list of candidates for the 2010 general election
lines.name: English

lines.value: two sitting mps ineke van gent and femke halsema were granted dispensation to stand for a fourth term
lines.name: English

lines.value: halsema was reelected as party leader
lines.name: English

lines.value: van gent was put as fifth on the party list
lines.name: English

lines.value: all of the first five candidates were sitting mps and four were women
lines.name: English

lines.value: their other high newcomers were former greenpeace director liesbeth van tongeren and chairman of cnv youth jesse klaver
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party won 10 seats in the election and participated in the formation talks of a green/purple government
lines.name: English

lines.value: the name groenlinks until 1992 groen links with a space between groen and links is a compromise between the ppr and the cpn and the psp
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ppr wanted the word green in the name of the party the psp and the cpn the word left
lines.name: English

lines.value: it also emphasises the core ideals of the party environmental sustainability and social justice
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1984 the common list of the ppr psp and cpn for the 1984 european elections was called green progressive accord - at that time the ppr did not want to accept the word left in the name of the political combination
lines.name: English

lines.value: the parties had entered in the 1989 european elections as the rainbow regenboog in reference to the rainbow group in the european parliament between 1984 and 1989
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party combines green and left wing ideals
lines.name: English

lines.value: the core ideals of greenleft are codified in the party's programme of principles called partij voor de toekomst - party for the future
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party places itself in the freedom loving tradition of the left
lines.name: English

lines.value: its principles include halsema the former political leader of the party has started a debate about the ideological course of greenleft
lines.name: English

lines.value: she emphasised the freedom loving tradition of the left and chose freedom as a key value
lines.name: English

lines.value: her course is called left liberal by herself and observers although halsema herself claims that she does not want to force an ideological change
lines.name: English

lines.value: following isaiah berlin halsema distinguishes between positive and negative freedom
lines.name: English

lines.value: negative freedom is according to halsema the freedom of citizens from government influence she applies this concept especially to the multicultural society and the rechtsstaat where the government should protect the rights of citizens and not limit them
lines.name: English

lines.value: positive freedom is the emancipation of citizens from poverty and discrimination
lines.name: English

lines.value: halsema wants to apply this concept to welfare state and the environment where government should take more action
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to halsema greenleft is an undogmatic party that has anarchist tendencies
lines.name: English

lines.value: the election manifesto for the 2010 elections was adopted in april of that year
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was titled klaar voor de toekomst prepared for the future
lines.name: English

lines.value: the manifesto emphasises international cooperation welfare state reform environmental policy and social tolerance
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft considers itself a social reform party which aims to reform the government finances and increase the position of outsiders on the labour market such as migrant youth single parents workers with short term contracts and people with disabilities
lines.name: English

lines.value: it disagrees with the parties on the right which in the eyes of greenleft were only oriented towards cutting costs and did not offer the worst off a chance for work emancipation and participation
lines.name: English

lines.value: but unlike the other opposition parties of the left the party does not want to defend the current welfare state - which the party calls powerless because it merely offers the worst off a benefit rather than prospects for work
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party wants to reform the dutch welfare state so it will benefit outsiders - those who have been excluded from the welfare state until now
lines.name: English

lines.value: to increase employment the greenleft proposes a participation contract where unemployment recipients sign an agreement with their local council to become involved in volunteer work schooling or work experience projects - for which they get paid minimum wage
lines.name: English

lines.value: the unemployment benefit should be increased and limited to one year
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this period people would have to look for a job or education
lines.name: English

lines.value: if at the end of the year one should not succeed in finding a job the government will offer one a job for the minimum wage
lines.name: English

lines.value: in order to create more employment they want to implement the green tax shift which will lower taxes on lower paid labour
lines.name: English

lines.value: this would be compensated by higher taxes on pollution
lines.name: English

lines.value: in order to increase prospects for the underprivileged it wants to invest in education especially the vmbo middle-level vocational education
lines.name: English

lines.value: in order to ensure that migrants have a better chance for jobs it wants to deal firmly with discrimination especially on the labour market
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party wants to decrease income differences by making child benefits
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party favours reform of government pensions after 45 years of employment one should get the right to a pension
lines.name: English

lines.value: if one starts working young one is able to stop working earlier than if one starts working when one is older
lines.name: English

lines.value: receiving unemployment or disability benefits is counted as work as is caring for children or family members
lines.name: English

lines.value: the system of mortgage interest deductions should be abolished over a forty year period
lines.name: English

lines.value: international cooperation is an important theme for the party
lines.name: English

lines.value: this includes development cooperation with underdeveloped countries
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft wants to increase spending on development aid to 0.8% of the gross national product
lines.name: English

lines.value: it wants to open the european markets to goods from third world countries under conditions of fair trade
lines.name: English

lines.value: in order to ensure free and fair trade it wants to increase and democratise international economic organisations such as the international monetary fund and the world bank
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party also favours greater international control over financial markets
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft favours european integration but is critical about the current policies of the european commission
lines.name: English

lines.value: it favoured the european constitution but after it was voted down in the 2005 referendum greenleft advocated a new treaty which emphasised democracy and subsidiarity
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party is critical about the war against terrorism
lines.name: English

lines.value: it wants to strengthen the peacekeeping powers of the united nations and reform the dutch armed forces into a peace force with the functions of nato to be taken over by the european union and the united nations
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft wants to solve environmental problems especially climate change by stimulating durable alternatives
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party wants to use taxes and emissions trading to stimulate alternative energy as an alternative to both fossil fuel and nuclear plants
lines.name: English

lines.value: it wants to close all nuclear plants in the netherlands and impose a tax on the use of coal in energy production in order to discourage the building of new coal based power plants
lines.name: English

lines.value: moreover it wants to stimulate energy saving
lines.name: English

lines.value: it wants to invest in clean public transport as an alternative to private transport
lines.name: English

lines.value: investments in public transport can be financed by not expanding highways and imposing tolls on the use of roads called rekening rijden
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party wants to stimulate organic farming through taxes as an alternative to industrial agriculture
lines.name: English

lines.value: moreover greenleft wants to codify animal rights in the constitution
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft values individual freedom and the rule of law
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party wants to legalise soft drugs
lines.name: English

lines.value: it wants to protect civil rights on the internet by extending constitutional protection for free communication to email and other modern technologies
lines.name: English

lines.value: it also favours a reform of copyright to allow non commercial reproduction and the use of open source software in the public sector
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the long term it seeks to abolish the monarchy and create a republic
lines.name: English

lines.value: it also favours a reduction of the size of the government bureaucracy for instance by decreasing the number of dutch ministries and abolishing the senate
lines.name: English

lines.value: finally greenleft favours liberal immigration and asylum policies
lines.name: English

lines.value: it wants to empower victims of human trafficking by giving them a residence permit and it wants to abolish the income requirements for marriage migration
lines.name: English

lines.value: this table shows the results of greenleft elections to the house of representatives hor senate s european parliament ep states provincial sp and municipal gr elections as well as the number of politicians in provincial gs and local executives aldermen
lines.name: English

lines.value: it also shows the party's political leadership the fractievoorzitter the chair of the parliamentary party and the lijsttrekker the party's top candidate in the general election
lines.name: English

lines.value: these posts are normally taken by the party leader
lines.name: English

lines.value: the member count and the partijvoorzitter the chair of the party's organisation are also shown
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party chair has an organisational function and is not part of the political leadership of the party
lines.name: English

lines.value: following the 2017 elections the party now has fourteen seats in the house of representatives
lines.name: English

lines.value: following the 2015 elections the party has four representatives in the senate
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the 2014 european parliament elections the party has two representatives in the european parliament
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the municipal level the party provides 8 mayors out of 414 as of december 2008 in smaller municipalities such as bloemendaal diemen and wormerland these are also appointed by the minister of the interior
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft did not perform particularly well in the 2006 municipal elections losing 14 of its 415 seats making it the fourth largest party in the netherlands on the municipal level
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the formation of municipal executives it was more successful and the number of municipal executives greenleft was part of grew from around 70 to around 100
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is part of the municipal executive of several larger cities notably nijmegen utrecht the hague leiden rotterdam and amsterdam where former mp marijke vos was alderwoman
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft has 70 members of borough level legislatures 53 in amsterdam and 17 in rotterdam
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the provincial level greenleft has provided one queen's commissioner out of 12 in north holland
lines.name: English

lines.value: queen's commissioners are appointed by the minister of the interior
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft is part of the north holland provincial executive
lines.name: English

lines.value: it holds 51 seats in provincial legislatures
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the following figure one can see the election results of the provincial election of 2007 per province
lines.name: English

lines.value: it shows the areas where greenleft is strong namely the urban areas like north holland and utrecht
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party is weaker in rural provinces like friesland and zeeland but also strong in rural groningen where the communist party of the netherlands one of the founding parties of greenleft was very strong
lines.name: English

lines.value: as can be seen on the map on the right greenleft tends to do particularly well in larger cities especially ones that host a university such as amsterdam where it scored 12.5% utrecht 12.2% and wageningen 11.8% nijmegen 10.4% and leiden 10.0%
lines.name: English

lines.value: more women vote for greenleft than men by a margin of 20%
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party also disproportionately appeals to homosexual voters
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party also polls well among migrant voters especially those from turkey and morocco where its support is twice as high as in the general population
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft voters have an eccentric position in their preferences for particular policies
lines.name: English

lines.value: between 1989 and 2003 they were the most leftwing voters in the netherlands often a little more to the left than voters of the sp
lines.name: English

lines.value: these voters are in favor of the redistribution of wealth free choice for euthanasia opening the borders for asylum seekers the multicultural society and are firmly against building new nuclear plants
lines.name: English

lines.value: the logo of greenleft is the name of the party with the word green written in red and the word left written in green since 1994
lines.name: English

lines.value: additional colours used in the logo are white yellow and blue
lines.name: English

lines.value: an earlier logo used between 1989 and 1994 and which can be seen on the poster above showed a variation of a peace sign projected on a green triangle on which ppr psp cpn evp was written and next to it greenleft in green and pink
lines.name: English

lines.value: many well known dutch people have supported greenleft election campaigns
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1989 choreographer rudi van dantzig and writer astrid roemer were last candidates
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2006 comedian vincent bijlo shared this position with mep kathalijne buitenweg
lines.name: English

lines.value: comedian sara kroos rapper raymzter astronaut wubbo ockels en soccer player khalid boulahrouz business man harry de winter journalist anil ramdas actrice kim van kooten commediene sanne wallis de vries comedian herman finkers artist herman van veen soccer player columnist jan mulder and writer geert mak have also committed their name to part of the 2006 or 2007 greenleft election campaign
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2004 singer ellen ten damme poet rutger kopland and presenter martijn krabbe supported the european election campaign
lines.name: English

lines.value: from 2007 onwards groenlinks has adopted the idea of a permanent campaign which implies that campaign activities are held even when there is no immediate connection to an election
lines.name: English

lines.value: permanent campaign activities are intended to create and maintain a base level of sympathy and knowledge about the party platform
lines.name: English

lines.value: the introduction of guerrilla gardening in the netherlands in 2008 was heavily supported by greenleft as part of the permanent campaign
lines.name: English

lines.value: the highest organ of greenleft is the party congress which is open to all members
lines.name: English

lines.value: the congress elects the party board it decides on the order of the candidates for national and european elections and it has a final say over the party platform
lines.name: English

lines.value: the congress convenes at least once every year in spring or when needed
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party board consists of fifteen members who are elected for a two year term
lines.name: English

lines.value: the chairperson of this board is the only paid position on the board the others are unpaid
lines.name: English

lines.value: the chairperson together with four other boardmembers the vice chair the treasurer the secretary the european secretary and the international secretary handles the daily affairs and meet every two weeks while the other ten board members meet only once a month
lines.name: English

lines.value: for the months that the congress does not convene a party council takes over its role
lines.name: English

lines.value: it consists out of 80 representatives of all the 250 municipal branches
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party board and the nationally elected representatives of the party are responsible to the party council
lines.name: English

lines.value: it has the right to fill vacancies in the board make changes to the party constitution and takes care of the party's finances
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft mps face relatively strong regulation mps are not allowed to run for more than three terms and a relatively high percentage of the income of mps is taken by the party
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft has 250 branches in nearly all dutch municipalities and each province
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are multiple municipalities in amsterdam and rotterdam where every borough has its own branch and they have federal branches at the municipal level
lines.name: English

lines.value: branches enjoy considerable independence and take care of their own campaigns lists of candidates and programs for elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: provincial congresses meet at least every year and municipal congresses more often
lines.name: English

lines.value: the total number of members of greenleft has been steadily increasing over the last ten years and had 23490 members in of january 2007
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are several independent organisations which are linked to greenleft
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft was founded as a mid sized party to the left of the labour party pvda
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1994 elections the socialist party sp also entered parliament
lines.name: English

lines.value: greenleft now takes a central position in the dutch left between the socialist sp which is more to the left and the social democratic pvda which is more to the centre
lines.name: English

lines.value: this position is exemplified by the call of femke halsema to form a left wing coalition after the 2006 elections knowing that such a coalition is only possible with greenleft
lines.name: English

lines.value: the electoral alliance between sp and gl in the 1998 2002 and 2006 elections and between greenleft and pvda in the 2004 european elections are examples of this position
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 2007 first chamber election it had an electoral alliance with the party for the animals
lines.name: English

lines.value: more and more however greenleft is seen as the most culturally progressive of the three parties
lines.name: English

lines.value: the was the radio broadcast in which japanese emperor hirohito emperor showa 昭和天皇 showa-tenno read out the announcing to the japanese people that the japanese government had accepted the potsdam declaration demanding the unconditional surrender of the japanese military at the end of world war ii
lines.name: English

lines.value: this speech was broadcast at noon japan standard time on august 15 1945
lines.name: English

lines.value: the speech was probably the first time that an emperor of japan had spoken albeit via a phonograph record to the common people
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was delivered in the formal classical japanese that few ordinary people could easily understand
lines.name: English

lines.value: it made no direct reference to a surrender of japan instead stating that the government had been instructed to accept the terms of the potsdam declaration fully
lines.name: English

lines.value: this created confusion in the minds of many listeners who were not sure whether japan had surrendered
lines.name: English

lines.value: the poor audio quality of the radio broadcast as well as the formal courtly language in which the speech was composed worsened the confusion
lines.name: English

lines.value: a digitally remastered version of the broadcast was released on 30 june 2015
lines.name: English

lines.value: the speech was not broadcast directly but was replayed from a phonograph recording made in the tokyo imperial palace on either august 13 or 14 1945
lines.name: English

lines.value: many elements of the imperial japanese army were extremely opposed to the idea that hirohito was going to end the war as they believed that this was dishonourable
lines.name: English

lines.value: consequently as many as one thousand officers and soldiers raided the imperial palace on the evening of august 14 to destroy the recording
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rebels were confused by the layout of the imperial palace and were unable to find the recording which had been hidden in a pile of documents
lines.name: English

lines.value: the recording was successfully smuggled out of the palace in a laundry basket of women's underwear and broadcast the following day although another attempt was made to stop it from being played at the radio station
lines.name: English

lines.value: to ease the anticipated confusion at the conclusion of the speech a radio announcer clarified that the emperor's message did mean that japan was surrendering
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to french journalist robert guillain who was living in tokyo at the time upon the announcement's conclusion most japanese retreated into their homes or places of business for several hours to quietly absorb and contemplate the significance of the announcement
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the recording was played the record used for playing it disappeared in the post surrender chaos but a radio technician had secretly made a copy which was given to occupation authorities and is the source of all recordings available today
lines.name: English

lines.value: the original record was later recovered but is generally believed to have never again been played
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rescript was translated into english and was broadcast to overseas allies by at the same time
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the us the federal communications commission fcc recorded the broadcast and its entire text appeared in the new york times
lines.name: English

lines.value: the main subject of the speech was to announce the surrender of japan that hirohito ordered our government to communicate to the governments of the united states great britain republic of china and the soviet union that our empire accepts the provisions of their joint declaration in the speech hirohito noted that the war arose out of our sincere desire to ensure japan's self preservation and the stabilization of east asia [...] but the war situation has developed not necessarily to japan's advantage
lines.name: English

lines.value: he then stated moreover the enemy has begun to employ a new and most cruel bomb the power of which to do damage is indeed incalculable taking the toll of many innocent lives referring to the atomic bombings of hiroshima and nagasaki that occurred days before
lines.name: English

lines.value: he however did not mention the soviet invasion of manchuria and other japanese held territories that had also begun a few days before
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also said it is according to the dictates of time and fate that we have resolved to pave the way for a grand peace for all the generations to come by enduring the unendurable and suffering what is insufferable
lines.name: English

lines.value: as such she was intended to be the sixth and final member of the iowa class constructed
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the time of her construction she was the second ship of the united states navy to be named in honor of the us state of kentucky
lines.name: English

lines.value: like her sister ship laid down as one of the last pair of iowa class ahead of her kentucky was still under construction at the end of hostilities and became caught up in the post war draw down of the armed services
lines.name: English

lines.value: her construction was suspended twice during which times she served as a parts hulk
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1950s several proposals were made to complete the ship as a guided missile battleship abandoned primarily due to cost concerns and the rampant pace of evolving missile technology
lines.name: English

lines.value: kentucky ultimately was sold for scrap in 1958
lines.name: English

lines.value: kentucky was conceived in 1935 when the united states navy initiated design studies for the creation of an extended that was not restricted by the second london naval treaty
lines.name: English

lines.value: this resulting in one of the fast battleship designs planned in 1938 by the preliminary design branch at the bureau of construction and repair
lines.name: English

lines.value: the passage of the second vinson act in 1938 had cleared the way for construction of the four south dakota class battleships and the first two iowa class fast battleships those with the hull numbers bb 61 and bb 62
lines.name: English

lines.value: the latter four battleships of the class those designated with the hull numbers bb 63 bb 64 bb 65 and bb 66 missouri wisconsin illinois and kentucky respectively were not cleared for construction until 12 july 1940
lines.name: English

lines.value: while bb 63 and bb 64 were originally planned as the final ships in the iowa class to serve as fast escorts for the s bb 65 and bb 66 were intended to be the first ships of the montana class which was larger and slower while mounting twelve mark 7 guns
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the passage of an emergency war building program on 19 july 1940 resulting in illinois and kentucky being reordered as the fifth and sixth ships respectively of the in order to save time on construction so the first ship of the would be reassigned as bb 67
lines.name: English

lines.value: the orders for bb 65 and bb 66 were placed on 9 september 1940 and the ships were laid down on 6 december 1942 and 7 march 1942 respectively
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1942 the united states navy shifted its building focus from battleships to aircraft carriers after the successes of carrier combat in both the battle of the coral sea and to a greater extent the battle of midway
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a result the construction of the us fleet of s had been given the highest priority for completion in the us shipyards by the us navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: the essex class carriers were proving vital to the war effort by enabling the allies to gain and maintain air supremacy in the pacific war and were rapidly becoming the principal striking arm of the united states navy in the ongoing effort to defeat the empire of japan
lines.name: English

lines.value: accordingly the united states accepted shortcomings in the armor of their s in favor of additional speed which could steam at a comparable speed with the essex class and provide the carriers with the maximum amount of anti aircraft protection
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a result construction of the was canceled before their keels could be laid
lines.name: English

lines.value: kentuckys main battery would have consisted of nine 50 cal mark 7 guns which could hurl armor piercing shells some
lines.name: English

lines.value: her secondary battery would have consisted of 20 38 cal guns arranged in 10 turrets which could fire at targets up to away
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the advent of air power and the mandate to gain and maintain air superiority came a need to protect the growing fleet of allied aircraft carriers
lines.name: English

lines.value: to this end kentucky was to be fitted with an array of oerlikon 20 mm and bofors 40 mm anti aircraft guns to defend allied carriers from enemy airstrikes
lines.name: English

lines.value: like iowa class ships from missouri hull number bb 63 onwards the frontal bulkhead armor was increased from the original to in order to better protect against fire from frontal sectors
lines.name: English

lines.value: because the iowa class torpedo defense was virtually the same as the preceding south dakota class battleships it was proposed that illinoiss and kentuckys hull be redesigned to provide a greater degree of torpedo protection for the battleship
lines.name: English

lines.value: under the original construction schematics for the class each side of the ship was protected below the waterline by two tanks mounted outside the belt armor and separated by a bulkhead
lines.name: English

lines.value: these tanks were initially planned to be empty but in practice were filled with water or fuel oil
lines.name: English

lines.value: the armored belt tapered to a thickness of 4 in below the waterline
lines.name: English

lines.value: behind the armored belt there was a void and then another bulkhead
lines.name: English

lines.value: the outer hull was intended to detonate a torpedo with the outer two compartments absorbing the shock and with any splinters or debris being stopped by the armored belt and the empty compartment behind it
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1939 the navy discovered that this system was less effective than the earlier torpedo defense system of the north carolina class due to the excessive rigidity of the lower belt armor causing leakage into adjacent compartments
lines.name: English

lines.value: subsequently the design of the torpedo defense system was modified for illinois and kentucky such as eliminating knuckles along certain holding bulkheads the intended construction format was estimated to provide up to 20% improvement to the torpedo defense of the battleship while simultaneously reducing flooding in the event of a torpedo strike
lines.name: English

lines.value: kentuckys construction was plagued by suspensions
lines.name: English

lines.value: her keel was laid down at the norfolk navy yard portsmouth virginia on 7 march 1942
lines.name: English

lines.value: however work on the ship was suspended in june that year and kentuckys bottom structure was launched to make room for lst construction on 10 june
lines.name: English

lines.value: while her construction was suspended the bureau of ships considered an aircraft carrier conversion proposal for kentucky and illinois in the aftermath of the battles of coral sea and midway
lines.name: English

lines.value: as proposed the converted kentucky would have had an long by wide flight deck with armament identical to the carriers of the : four twin 5-inch gun mounts and four more 5-inch guns in single mounts along with six 40 mm quadruple mounts
lines.name: English

lines.value: the idea was abandoned after the bureau of ships decided that the converted ships would carry fewer aircraft than the essex class that more essex class carriers could be built in the same amount of time and that the conversion project would be significantly more expensive than new essexes
lines.name: English

lines.value: instead kentucky and illinois were to be completed as battleships but their construction was given very low priority
lines.name: English

lines.value: work on the ship resumed on 6 december 1944 when the keel structure was returned to the slipway
lines.name: English

lines.value: work on the battleship proceeded at a slow pace and her completion was projected for the third quarter of 1946
lines.name: English

lines.value: in december 1945 it was recommended that kentucky be completed as an anti aircraft battleship and work on the ship was suspended in august 1946 while this was considered
lines.name: English

lines.value: construction resumed again on 17 august 1948 without any decision having been made on her final design
lines.name: English

lines.value: work on kentucky continued until 20 january 1950 when it was decided to halt work on the ship
lines.name: English

lines.value: following this she was floated out of her drydock to clear a space for repairs to sister ship which had run aground en route from hampton roads
lines.name: English

lines.value: as early as 1946 missile conversion projects for kentucky and the incomplete large cruiser were discussed
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the early 1950s the advances in guided missile technology led to a proposal to create a large warship armed with both guns and missiles
lines.name: English

lines.value: to this end the incomplete kentucky was chosen for conversion from an all gun ship into a guided missile battleship
lines.name: English

lines.value: this proposal would have been relatively conservative and would have involved the installation of a pair of twin arm launchers for the rim 2 terrier surface to air missile sam on the aft deckhouse with a pair of antennas for the associated an/apg 55 pulse doppler interception radar installed forward of these and the an/sps 2b air search radar on a short mast
lines.name: English

lines.value: since the battleship was already approximately 73% complete construction had been halted at the second deck installation of the missile system and associated electronics would have involved only adding the necessary equipment without any need to rebuild the ship to accommodate the system
lines.name: English

lines.value: some guided missile concepts included one or two launchers for eight regulus ii or ssm n 2 triton nuclear cruise missiles
lines.name: English

lines.value: the guided missile battleship project was authorized in 1954 and kentucky was renumbered from bb 66 to bbg 1 with the conversion due to be complete in 1956
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the project was soon cancelled with the conversion ideas transferred to a smaller platform that led to the guided missile cruiser
lines.name: English

lines.value: these partial conversions of two heavy cruisers proved only partially successful in their new role as the pace of change in cruise missile technology rendered their new weapons systems obsolete while their remaining heavy guns proved in demand
