lines.value: father divine c
lines.name: English

lines.value: 1876september 10 1965 also known as reverend m j divine was an african american spiritual leader from about 1907 until his death
lines.name: English

lines.value: his full self given name was reverend major jealous divine and he was also known as the messenger early in his life
lines.name: English

lines.value: he founded the international peace mission movement formulated its doctrine and oversaw its growth from a small and predominantly black congregation into a multiracial and international church
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine claimed to be god
lines.name: English

lines.value: he made numerous contributions toward his followers economic independence and racial equality
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was a contemporary of other religious leaders such as daddy grace charles harrison mason noble drew ali and james f jones also known as prophet jones
lines.name: English

lines.value: little is known about father divine's early life or even his real given name
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine and the peace movement he started did not keep many records
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine himself declined several offers to write his biography saying that the history of god would not be useful in mortal terms
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also refused to acknowledge relationship to any family
lines.name: English

lines.value: newspapers in the 1930s had to dig up his probable given name george baker
lines.name: English

lines.value: this name is not recognized by the library of congress and from 1979 there is no further use of that name as a heading for father divine in libraries catalogs federal bureau of investigation files record his name as george baker alias god
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1936 eliza mayfield claimed to be father divine's mother
lines.name: English

lines.value: she stated that his real name was frederick edwards from hendersonville north carolina and had abandoned a wife and five children although mayfield offered no proof and claimed to not remember his father's name
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine replied that god has no mother father divine's childhood remains a contentious point
lines.name: English

lines.value: some especially earlier researchers suppose that he was born in the deep south most likely in georgia as the son of sharecroppers
lines.name: English

lines.value: newer research by jill watts based on census data finds evidence for a george baker jr of appropriate age born in an african american enclave of rockville maryland called monkey run
lines.name: English

lines.value: if this theory is correct his mother was a former slave named nancy baker who died in may 1897
lines.name: English

lines.value: most researchers agree that father divine's parents were freed african american slaves
lines.name: English

lines.value: notoriously poor records were kept about this generation of african americans so controversy about his upbringing is not likely to be resolved
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the other hand he and his first wife peninnah claimed that they married on june 6 1882
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine was probably called george baker around the turn of the century
lines.name: English

lines.value: he worked as a gardener in baltimore maryland
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a 1906 sojourn in california father divine became acquainted with the ideas of charles fillmore and the new thought movement a philosophy of positive thinking that would inform his later doctrines
lines.name: English

lines.value: among other things this belief system asserted that negative thoughts led to poverty and unhappiness
lines.name: English

lines.value: songwriter johnny mercer credited a father divine sermon for inspiring the title of his song accentuate the positive
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine attended a local baptist church often preaching until 1907 when a traveling preacher called samuel morris spoke and was expelled from the congregation
lines.name: English

lines.value: morris originally from allegheny county pennsylvania had a soft spoken and uncontroversial sermon until the end when he raised his arms and shouted i am the eternal father this routine had him thrown out of many churches in baltimore and was apparently unsuccessful until morris happened upon the receptive father divine
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his late 20s father divine became morris's first follower and adopted a pseudonym the messenger
lines.name: English

lines.value: the messenger was a christ figure to morris's god the father
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine preached with morris in baltimore out of the home of former evangelist harriette snowden who came to accept their divinity
lines.name: English

lines.value: morris began calling himself father jehovia divine and father jehovia were later joined by john a hickerson who called himself reverend bishop saint john the vine
lines.name: English

lines.value: john the vine shared the messenger's excellent speaking ability and his interest in new thought
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1912 the three man ministry collapsed as john the vine denied father jehovia's monopoly on godhood citing 1 john 4:15 to mean god was in everyone :"whoever shall confess that jesus is the son of god god dwells in him and he in god father divine had finally parted ways with his former associates
lines.name: English

lines.value: denying that father jehovia was god and saying that everyone could not be god he declared that he himself was god and the only true expression of god's spirit
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine traveled south where he preached extensively in georgia
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1913 conflicts with local ministers led to him being sentenced to 60 days in a chain gang
lines.name: English

lines.value: while he was serving his sentence several prison inspectors were injured in an auto accident which he viewed as the direct result of their disbelief
lines.name: English

lines.value: upon his release he attracted a following of mostly black women in valdosta georgia
lines.name: English

lines.value: he taught celibacy and the rejection of gender categorizations
lines.name: English

lines.value: on february 6 1914 several followers husbands and local preachers had divine arrested for lunacy
lines.name: English

lines.value: this actually expanded his ministry with reporters and worshippers deluging his prison cell
lines.name: English

lines.value: some whites even began calling on him
lines.name: English

lines.value: former mercer university professor and lay preacher j r moseley of macon georgia befriended divine and arranged for j b copeland a mercer alum and respected valdosta lawyer to represent him pro bono
lines.name: English

lines.value: moseley was interested in what he termed this unusual man in his autobiography manifest destiny decades later in the 1930s moseley met divine in new york city when he received word that the man going by that name might in fact be the same person he met in georgia
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine was found mentally sound in spite of maniacal beliefs
lines.name: English

lines.value: he had given no name when arrested and was tried as john doe alias god
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1914 father divine traveled to brooklyn new york with a small number of followers and an all black congregation
lines.name: English

lines.value: although he claimed to be god incarnate fulfilling biblical prophecy he lived relatively quietly
lines.name: English

lines.value: he and his disciples formed a commune in a black middle class apartment building
lines.name: English

lines.value: he forbade sex alcohol tobacco and gambling among those who were living with him
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1919 he had adopted the name reverend major jealous divine
lines.name: English

lines.value: reverend major was chosen as a title of respect and authority while jealous was a reference to exodus 34:14 where the lord says he is a jealous god and that god's name is jealous
lines.name: English

lines.value: exodus 34:14 his followers affectionately called him father divine
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this period father divine married a follower penninah who was decades his senior
lines.name: English

lines.value: like father divine her early life is obscure but she is believed to be from macon georgia
lines.name: English

lines.value: the date of the marriage is unknown but probably occurred between 1914 and 1917
lines.name: English

lines.value: in addition to lending her dignified look to father divine penninah served to defuse rumors of impropriety between him and his many young female followers
lines.name: English

lines.value: both penninah who was often called mother divine and father divine would assert that the marriage was never physically consummated
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine and his disciples moved to sayville new york on long island in 1919
lines.name: English

lines.value: he and his followers were the first black homeowners in town
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine purchased his 72 macon street house from a resident who wanted to spite the neighbor he was feuding with
lines.name: English

lines.value: the two neighbors both german americans began fighting when one of them changed his name from felgenhauer to fellows in response to anti german sentiment
lines.name: English

lines.value: his neighbor taunted him and the feud escalated until fellows decided to move
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a final insult he specifically advertised his home for sale to a colored buyer to presumably lower his neighbors property values
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this period his movement underwent sustained growth
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine held free weekly banquets and helped newcomers find jobs
lines.name: English

lines.value: he began attracting many white followers as well as black
lines.name: English

lines.value: the integrated environment of father divine's communal house and the apparently flaunted wealth of his cadillac infuriated neighbors
lines.name: English

lines.value: members of the overwhelmingly white community accused him of maintaining a large harem and engaging in scandalous sex although the suffolk county district attorney's office found the claims baseless
lines.name: English

lines.value: nonetheless the neighbors continued to complain
lines.name: English

lines.value: on may 8 1931 a sayville deputy arrested and charged father divine with disturbing the peace
lines.name: English

lines.value: remarkable during the depression father divine submitted his $1000 bail in cash
lines.name: English

lines.value: the trial not as speedy as the neighbors wanted was scheduled for late fall allowing father divine's popularity to snowball for the entire sayville vacation season
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine held banquets for as many as 3000 people that summer
lines.name: English

lines.value: cars clogging the streets for these gatherings bolstered some neighbors claims that father divine was a disturbance to the peace and furthermore was hurting their property values
lines.name: English

lines.value: on sunday november 15 at 12:15 am a police officer was called to father divine's raucously loud property
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the time state troopers deputies and prison buses were called in a mob of neighbors had surrounded the compound
lines.name: English

lines.value: fearing a riot the police informed father divine and his followers that they had fifteen minutes to disperse
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine had them wait in silence for ten minutes and then they filed into police custody
lines.name: English

lines.value: processed by the county jail at 3 am clerks were frustrated because the followers often refused to give their usual names and stubbornly offered the inspired names they adopted in the movement
lines.name: English

lines.value: seventy eight people were arrested altogether including fifteen whites
lines.name: English

lines.value: forty six pleaded guilty to disturbing the peace and incurred $5 fines which father divine paid with a $500 bill which the court was embarrassingly unable to make change from
lines.name: English

lines.value: penninah father divine and thirty followers resisted the charges
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine's arrest and heterodox doctrines were sensationally reported
lines.name: English

lines.value: the new york frenzy made this event and its repercussions the single most famous moment of father divine's life
lines.name: English

lines.value: although mostly inaccurate articles on father divine propelled his popularity
lines.name: English

lines.value: by december his followers began renting buildings in new york city for father divine to speak in
lines.name: English

lines.value: soon he often had several engagements on a single night
lines.name: English

lines.value: on december 20 he spoke to an estimated 10000 in harlem's rockland palace a spacious former basketball venue manhattan casino
lines.name: English

lines.value: by may 1932 meetings were regularly held at the rockland and throughout new york and new jersey
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine had supporters in washington state california and throughout the world thanks to new thought devotees like eugene del mar an early convert and former harlem journalist and henry joerns the publisher of a new thought magazine in seattle
lines.name: English

lines.value: curiously although the movement was predominantly black followers outside the northeast were mostly middle class whites
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this period of expansions several branch communes were opened in new york and new jersey
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine's followers finally named the movement the international peace mission movement
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine's trial was finally held on may 24 1932
lines.name: English

lines.value: his lawyer ellee j lovelace a prominent harlem african american and former us attorney had requested the trial be moved outside of suffolk county due to potential jury bias
lines.name: English

lines.value: the court acquiesced and the trial took place at the nassau county supreme court before justice lewis j smith
lines.name: English

lines.value: the jury found him guilty on june 5 but asked for leniency on behalf of father divine
lines.name: English

lines.value: ignoring this request justice smith lectured on how father divine was a fraud and menace to society before issuing the maximum sentence for disturbing the peace one year in prison and a $500 fine
lines.name: English

lines.value: smith 55 died of a heart attack days later on june 9 1932
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine was widely reported to have commented on the death i hated to do it in fact he wrote to his followers i did not desire judge smith to die i did desire that my spirit would touch his heart and change his mind that he might repent and believe and be saved from the grave the impression that justice smith's death was divine retribution was perpetuated by the press which failed to report smith's prior heart problems and implied the death to be more sudden and unexpected than it was
lines.name: English

lines.value: during his brief prison stay father divine read prodigiously notably on the scottsboro nine
lines.name: English

lines.value: after his attorneys secured release through an appeal on june 25 1932 he declared that the foundational documents of the united states of america such as the constitution and declaration of independence were inspired
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine also taught that contemporary leaders strayed from these ideals but he would become increasingly patriotic through his life
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine moved to harlem new york where he had accumulated significant following in the black community
lines.name: English

lines.value: members rather than father divine himself held most deeds for the movement but they contributed toward father divine's comfortable lifestyle
lines.name: English

lines.value: purchasing several hotels which they called heavens members could live and seek jobs inexpensively
lines.name: English

lines.value: the movement also opened several budget enterprises including restaurants and clothing shops that sold cheaply by cutting overhead
lines.name: English

lines.value: these proved very successful in the depression
lines.name: English

lines.value: economical cash only businesses were actually part of father divine's doctrine
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1934 branches had opened in los angeles california and seattle washington and gatherings occurred in france switzerland canada and australia but the membership totals were drastically overstated in the press
lines.name: English

lines.value: time magazine estimated nearly two million followers but the true figure of adherents was probably a few tens of thousands and a larger body of sympathizers who attended his gatherings
lines.name: English

lines.value: nonetheless father divine was increasingly called upon to offer political endorsements which he initially did not
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example new york mayoral candidates john p o'brien and fiorello h laguardia each sought his endorsement in 1933 but father divine was apparently uninterested
lines.name: English

lines.value: an odd alliance between father divine and the communist party of america began in early 1934
lines.name: English

lines.value: although father divine was outspokenly capitalist he was impressed with the party's commitment to civil rights
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party relished the endorsement although contemporary fbi records indicate some critics of the perceived huckster were expelled from the party for protesting the alliance
lines.name: English

lines.value: in spite of this alliance the movement was largely apolitical until the harlem riot of 1935
lines.name: English

lines.value: based on a rumor of police killing a black teenager it left four dead and caused over $1 million in property damage in father divine's neighborhood
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine's outrage at this and other racial injustices fueled a keener interest in politics
lines.name: English

lines.value: in january 1939 the movement organized the first ever divine righteous government convention which crafted political platforms incorporating the doctrine of father divine
lines.name: English

lines.value: among other things the delegates opposed school segregation and many of franklin delano roosevelt's social programs which they interpreted as handouts
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the zenith of father divine's influence several misfortunes struck the movement
lines.name: English

lines.value: on december 16 john hunt a white millionaire and disciple from california calling himself john the revelator met the jewett family of denver colorado
lines.name: English

lines.value: he kidnapped their 17-year-old daughter delight and took her back to california without her parents consent
lines.name: English

lines.value: renaming her virgin mary john the revelator began sexual relations with her
lines.name: English

lines.value: he announced that she would give birth to a new redeemer by immaculate conception in hawaii
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine summoned hunt to new york separated the couple and chastised his eccentric follower
lines.name: English

lines.value: the jewetts finding their daughter apparently brainwashed into believing she was literally the virgin mary demanded compensation
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the movement's attorneys conducted an internal investigation they refused
lines.name: English

lines.value: outraged the jewetts offered their story to william randolph hearst's new york evening journal an established critic of the movement
lines.name: English

lines.value: after a manhunt and trial john hunt was sentenced to three years and adopted a new name the prodigal son
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine publicly endorsed the conviction of john the revelator contrary to some expectations some followers expected him to once again "" the judge
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the scandal brought bad publicity to father divine
lines.name: English

lines.value: news coverage implied his followers were gullible and dangerous
lines.name: English

lines.value: in march 1937 penninah fell ill in kingston new york
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine rarely comforted her on what was widely believed to be her deathbed
lines.name: English

lines.value: he kept running the church only visiting her once in kingston again causing bad publicity
lines.name: English

lines.value: penninah however claimed that she was not seriously ill or in pain
lines.name: English

lines.value: on april 20 1937 a violent outburst occurred in a meeting when two men tried to deliver father divine a summons
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of the men harry green was stabbed as father divine fled
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine went into hiding to evade authorities
lines.name: English

lines.value: during this time one of father divine's most prominent followers called faithful mary defected and took control of a large commune which was technically in her name
lines.name: English

lines.value: of the father she said he's just a damned man she furthermore alleged that he defrauded his followers to maintain a rich lifestyle for himself
lines.name: English

lines.value: faithful mary also made a number of sexual allegations including a charge that father divine coerced women to have sex with key disciples
lines.name: English

lines.value: in early may father divine was located and extradited from connecticut and faced criminal charges in new york
lines.name: English

lines.value: that summer hearst's metronone newsreel distributed mocking footage of father divine's followers singing outside police headquarters glory glory hallelujah
lines.name: English

lines.value: our god is in our land later in may 1937 an ex follower called verinda brown filed a lawsuit for $4476 against father divine
lines.name: English

lines.value: the browns had entrusted their savings with father divine in sayville back in 1931
lines.name: English

lines.value: they left the movement in 1935 wishing to live as husband and wife again but were unable to get their money back
lines.name: English

lines.value: in light of their evidence and testimony from faithful mary and others critical of the movement the court ordered repayment of the money
lines.name: English

lines.value: however this opened up an enormous potential liability from all ex devotees so father divine resisted and appealed the judgment
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1938 father divine was cleared of criminal charges and mother divine recovered
lines.name: English

lines.value: faithful mary impoverished and broken returned to the movement
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine made her grovel for forgiveness which she did
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the late 1930s the movement stabilized although it had clearly passed its zenith
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine's political focus on anti lynching measures became more resolved
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1940 his followers had gathered 250000 signatures in favor of an anti lynching bill he wrote
lines.name: English

lines.value: however passage of such statutes came slowly in new york and elsewhere
lines.name: English

lines.value: the verinda brown lawsuit against father dragged on and was sustained on appeal
lines.name: English

lines.value: in july 1942 he was ordered to pay brown or face contempt of court
lines.name: English

lines.value: instead father divine fled the state and reestablished his headquarters in philadelphia pennsylvania
lines.name: English

lines.value: he still visited new york however
lines.name: English

lines.value: state law forbade serving subpoenas in new york on sunday so he often spoke on the sabbath day in harlem the promised land his kingston commune and sayville
lines.name: English

lines.value: after moving to philadelphia father divine's wife penninah died
lines.name: English

lines.value: the exact date is not known because father divine never talked about it or even acknowledged her death
lines.name: English

lines.value: however it occurred sometime in 1943 and biographers believe penninah's death rattled father divine making him aware of his own mortality
lines.name: English

lines.value: it became obvious to father divine and his followers that his doctrine might not make one immortal as he asserted at least not in the flesh
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1944 singer songwriter johnny mercer came to hear of one of divine's sermons
lines.name: English

lines.value: the subject was you got to accentuate the positive and eliminate the negative mercer said wow that's a colorful phrase he went back to hollywood and got together with songwriter harold arlen over the rainbow and together they wrote ac cent tchu ate the positive which was recorded by mercer himself and the pied pipers in 1945
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was also recorded by bing crosby with the andrews sisters that same year.after his first wife died father divine married a white canadian woman called edna rose ritchings in washington dc on april 29 1946
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ceremony was kept secret even from most members until ritching's visa expired
lines.name: English

lines.value: critics of the movement believed that father divine's seemingly scandalous marriage to 21-year-old ritchings would destroy the movement
lines.name: English

lines.value: instead most followers rejoiced and the marriage date became a celebrated anniversary in the movement
lines.name: English

lines.value: to prove that he and ritchings adhered to his doctrine on sexual abstinence father divine assigned a black female follower to be her constant companion
lines.name: English

lines.value: he claimed that ritchings later called mother s a divine was the reincarnation of penninah
lines.name: English

lines.value: reincarnation was not previously part of father divine's doctrine and did not become a fixture of his theology
lines.name: English

lines.value: followers believed that penninah was an exceptional case and viewed her return as a miracle
lines.name: English

lines.value: going into the 1950s the press rarely covered father divine and when it did it was no longer as a menace but as an amusing relic
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example light hearted stories ran when father divine announced philadelphia was capital of the world and when he claimed to inspire invention of the hydrogen bomb
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine's predominantly lower class following ebbed as the economy swelled
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1953 follower john devoute gave father divine woodmont a 72-acre 0.3 km² hilltop estate in gladwyne pennsylvania outside of philadelphia
lines.name: English

lines.value: this french gothic manor served as his home and primary site of his increasingly infrequent banquets until his death in 1965
lines.name: English

lines.value: as his health declined he continued to petition for civil rights
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1951 he advocated reparations to be paid to the descendants of slaves
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also argued in favor of integrated neighborhoods
lines.name: English

lines.value: however he did not participate in the burgeoning american civil rights movement because of his poor health and especially his dislike of the use of racial labels denying he was black
lines.name: English

lines.value: on september 10 1965 father divine died of natural causes at his woodmont estate
lines.name: English

lines.value: his widow and remaining followers insist his spirit is still alive and always refer to father divine in the present tense
lines.name: English

lines.value: believers keep the furnishings of father divine's personal rooms at woodmont just as they were as a shrine to his life
lines.name: English

lines.value: edna rose ritchings became spiritual leader of the movement
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1972 she fought an attempt by jim jones to take over the movement's dwindling devotees
lines.name: English

lines.value: jones based some of his doctrines on the international peace mission movement and claimed to be the reincarnation of father divine
lines.name: English

lines.value: although a few members of the mission joined peoples temple after jones made his play for leadership of the movement the power push was in terms of its ultimate objective a complete failure
lines.name: English

lines.value: that jones was 34 years old at the time of father divine's death made his claims of being a new incarnation rather hard to sustain jones claimed divine's spirit had entered his body upon the passing of the elder man and ritchings was left unimpressed by jones impassioned rhetoric
lines.name: English

lines.value: jones custom of tape recording all his sermons was copied from divine who spoke to his followers via archived sermon tapes once ill health forced him to cease speaking at meetings
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine was a lightly built african american man at a diminutive 5'2 1.57 m
lines.name: English

lines.value: through most of his life he maintained a fastidious appearance and a neat moustache that he kept well groomed his hair was invariably neatly combed and since his days in sayville new york he almost always wore a suit in public
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine was said to be very charismatic
lines.name: English

lines.value: his sermons were emotionally moving and freely associated between topics
lines.name: English

lines.value: his speech was often peppered with words of his own invention like physicalating and tangiblated
lines.name: English

lines.value: an attendee at a harlem kingdoms meeting in the 1930s recalled that he rhythmically intoned tens hundreds thousands ten thousands hundred thousands millions
lines.name: English

lines.value: tens hundreds millions although this seemed nonsense to the visitor he reported that at the end the true believers chanted yes he's god
lines.name: English

lines.value: yes he's god other eccentricities were drawn from his doctrine
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example nearly every sermon began with the greeting and exhortation peace father divine believed that peace should replace hello
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine preached of his divinity even before he was known as father divine in the late 1910s
lines.name: English

lines.value: his doctrine taught that his life fulfilled all biblical prophecies about the second coming regarding himself as jesus christ reborn
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine also lectured that christ existed in every joint of his follower's bodies and that he was god's light incarnated in order to show people how to establish heaven on earth and to show them the way to eternal life
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example father divine's definition of god became quite celebrated at the time because of its unusual use of language god is not only personified and materialized
lines.name: English

lines.value: he is repersonified and rematerialized
lines.name: English

lines.value: he rematerialized and he rematerialates
lines.name: English

lines.value: he rematerialates and he is rematerializatable
lines.name: English

lines.value: he repersonificates and he repersonifitizes
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine can be considered part of the new thought movement indeed many of his white followers came from this tradition
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine was particularly concerned with the downtrodden of society including but not limited to blacks
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was opposed to people accepting welfare
lines.name: English

lines.value: scholars disagree about whether father divine an african american was a civil rights activist but he certainly advocated some progressive changes to race relations
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example because he believed that every human was accorded equal rights he believed that all members of lynch mobs ought to be tried and convicted as murderers
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine's anti lynching campaigns resonated in the black ghettos where his congregations lived and he got over a quarter million people to sign his anti lynching proposals
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine advocated that followers think of themselves as simply americans
lines.name: English

lines.value: he believed that america was the birthplace of the kingdom of god which would ultimately encompass truths of all religious principles promoting equality and brotherhood
lines.name: English

lines.value: the movement was supportive of the united states declaration of independence the constitution and particularly the bill of rights as inspired documents believing that they outlined a more ideal life
lines.name: English

lines.value: toward this life followers of father divine owned and managed property collectively
lines.name: English

lines.value: the movement strove to alleviate poverty by feeding the poor and through education in written english which the movement believed was the universal language
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine established an international modesty code which forbids smoking drinking and profanity
lines.name: English

lines.value: additionally it forbade tips bribes receiving presents and undue mixing of the sexes along with women wearing slacks or short skirts and men wearing short sleeves
lines.name: English

lines.value: although father divine himself was married the movement discouraged marriage along with any excessive mingling of the sexes
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the heavens and other living spaces the movement maintained separate areas existed for men and women
lines.name: English

lines.value: father divine advocated a number of economic practices which his followers abided by
lines.name: English

lines.value: he opposed life insurance which converts were to cancel welfare social security and credit
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus the movement advocated economic self sufficiency
lines.name: English

lines.value: his insistence that his followers refuse welfare not related to employment was estimated to have saved new york city $2 million during the depression
lines.name: English

lines.value: business owners in the movement named their ventures to show affiliation with father divine and obeyed all of these practices
lines.name: English

lines.value: they dealt only in cash refusing credit in any of its forms
lines.name: English

lines.value: each was to sell below competitor's prices while refusing any sorts of tips or gratuities
lines.name: English

lines.value: finally they refrained from trade in alcohol or tobacco
lines.name: English

lines.value: some biographers such as robert weisbrot speculate that father divine was a forerunner to the civil rights movement during the 1950s and 1960s heavily influenced by his upbringing in the segregated south
lines.name: English

lines.value: others such as jill watts reject not only this characterization but also the theory that father divine grew up in the deep south
lines.name: English

lines.value: watts asserts that rockville was less oppressive than the south or even baltimore maryland and believes his civil rights positions are unintelligible without evaluating them in the context of the doctrine of father divine
lines.name: English

lines.value: although father divine strove extensively against lynching and bigotry he accepted many of the negative characteristics assigned african americans
lines.name: English

lines.value: he concluded that those who identified themselves as black manifested these characteristics
lines.name: English

lines.value: in short he believed blacks perpetuated their own oppression by thinking racially
lines.name: English

lines.value: he once said that he was not poor because he did not belong to a poor downtrodden race—that he was not black
lines.name: English

lines.value: edna rose ritchings mother divine conducted services for the old and dwindling congregation until her death
lines.name: English

lines.value: the movement owns several properties such as father divine's gladwyne estate woodmont his former home in sayville new york and the circle mission church on broad street in philadelphia which also houses the movement's library
lines.name: English

lines.value: chapters exist in pennsylvania and possibly elsewhere but the movement is not centralized and exists through a number of interrelated groups
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2004 gastronomica magazine published an article about mother s a divine and the movement's feasts
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2000 the divine lorraine hotel near temple university on north broad street was sold off by the international peace mission movement
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was a budget hotel with separate floors for men and women in accord with father divine's teachings
lines.name: English

lines.value: the divine tracy hotel in west philadelphia was sold in 2006
lines.name: English

lines.value: * list of people who have been considered deities
lines.name: English

lines.value: hurt no more is the second studio album by r&b singer and musician mario winans released in 2004
lines.name: English

lines.value: winans recorded his second album hurt no more in 2001 2002 and 2003 in between his busy schedule working with other artists mostly on diddy's bad boy label
lines.name: English

lines.value: the album is based on stories of love and betrayal
lines.name: English

lines.value: on his website winans says this record is about relationships pure and simple
lines.name: English

lines.value: we all have hearts
lines.name: English

lines.value: sometimes we have to look deeper into what we're saying and doing to the people we care about all of the production work and most of the instrumental work on the album was performed by winans himself
lines.name: English

lines.value: hurt no more received mixed to positive reviews from music critics
lines.name: English

lines.value: allmusic rated the album as 4 stars out of 5 saying it was one of the best r and b albums of the year in contrast rolling stone rated it as two stars saying the lyrics lack punch and the songs never achieve the angst they should
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first single i don't wanna know was based on a sample of boadicea by enya from her 1987 self titled album
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fugees also sampled this track for their song ready or not from the album the score
lines.name: English

lines.value: the song features a rap by p diddy and radio programmers and club djs started playing the track when it started appearing on mixtapes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the song was released as the single in early 2004 and become a worldwide hit going to 1 in germany and the us rhythmic top 40 2 on the billboard hot 100 us r&b/ hip hop and world internet download charts and 3 on a composite world r&b chart based on the us uk germany france and australia australian and norwegian charts
lines.name: English

lines.value: it also reached the top ten of a composite european chart
lines.name: English

lines.value: hurt no more was released on april 20 2004 in the us and as at early june 2004 had reached 1 on the billboard r&b hip hop chart 2 on the us billboard 200 and 3 on the uk album charts
lines.name: English

lines.value: george magoffin humphrey march 8 1890january 20 1970 was an american lawyer businessman and banker
lines.name: English

lines.value: he served as the united states secretary of the treasury for president dwight d eisenhower
lines.name: English

lines.value: humphrey was born on march 8 1890 and raised in cheboygan michigan the son of caroline magoffin and watts sherman humphrey
lines.name: English

lines.value: he received both his undergraduate and law degrees from the university of michigan
lines.name: English

lines.value: on january 15 1913 humphrey married pamela stark
lines.name: English

lines.value: they had three children together cynthia pamela gilbert watts and caroline helen humphrey
lines.name: English

lines.value: after practicing law in his hometown for five years with his father's firm he accepted a position with steel manufacturer m a hanna company in 1917
lines.name: English

lines.value: that association lasted 35 years and included his ascension to company president in 1929
lines.name: English

lines.value: he served as chairman of the business council then known as the business advisory council for the united states department of commerce in 1946
lines.name: English

lines.value: following dwight eisenhower's election to the presidency in 1952 humphrey was recommended by close adviser general lucius d clay who had worked with the corporate magnate regarding post war plans in germany
lines.name: English

lines.value: as secretary of the treasury in the first republican administration in 20 years humphrey was one of the most influential of president eisenhower's cabinet members
lines.name: English

lines.value: eisenhower was once quoted as saying when george speaks we all listen humphrey had given up a $300000 salary to accept the cabinet position that paid just $22500
lines.name: English

lines.value: he fought to have a balanced budget tight money limits on welfare and foreign aid as well as trickle down tax cuts
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was even more adamant about government spending saying in a 1957 press conference that if it wasn't curbed you will have a depression that will curl your hair after leaving office on july 29 1957
lines.name: English

lines.value: following humphrey's departure that same year he returned to the hanna company serving as honorary board chairman and director then later became chairman of national steel corporation
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1962 humphrey became embroiled in a potential controversy when a senate committee investigated the stockpiling of nickel during his time in the cabinet
lines.name: English

lines.value: the $98 million deal involved companies he had once headed but he explained that his motivation was to increase the country's strategic stockpiles and was thus cleared
lines.name: English

lines.value: he made no profit from the deal
lines.name: English

lines.value: humphrey remained out of the spotlight for the next few years
lines.name: English

lines.value: his health deteriorated when he suffered an apparent heat stroke in august 1969
lines.name: English

lines.value: he then became a frequent visitor to hospitals until entering cleveland's university hospital cardiac unit on december 27 1969
lines.name: English

lines.value: he died on january 20 1970
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was buried at the lake view cemetery in cleveland ohio
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was the uncle of software engineer watts humphrey
lines.name: English

lines.value: *[https://eisenhower.archives.gov/research/finding_aids/pdf/humphrey_george_papers.pdf papers of george m humphrey dwight d eisenhower presidential library]
lines.name: English

lines.value: us highway 151 us 151 is a us highway that runs through the states of iowa and wisconsin
lines.name: English

lines.value: the southern terminus for us 151 is at a junction with interstate 80 in iowa county iowa and its northern terminus is at manitowoc wisconsin
lines.name: English

lines.value: the route from south to north follows a northeasterly path through iowa and wisconsin
lines.name: English

lines.value: approximately south of dubuque iowa us 151 joins with us 61
lines.name: English

lines.value: the two highways share a route from there to dickeyville wisconsin
lines.name: English

lines.value: south of dubuque us 61 us 151 join with us 52 and share a route with us 52 until the white street exit in dubuque
lines.name: English

lines.value: in wisconsin us 61/151 joins with wis 35 about north of the iowa wisconsin border
lines.name: English

lines.value: at dickeyville us 151 splits off and heads northeast to platteville
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 61 and wis 35 continue north
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 151 later joins with us 18 near dodgeville
lines.name: English

lines.value: the two highways share a route all the way to madison
lines.name: English

lines.value: us highway 151 starts at an intersection with interstate 80 i-80 in an isolated part of iowa near both williamsburg and conroy
lines.name: English

lines.value: it then continues through the area around the amana colonies where it has a brief overlap with us 6
lines.name: English

lines.value: once meeting up with us 30 and us 218 the route cuts around the city of cedar rapids while the business route 151 goes through the city
lines.name: English

lines.value: the route splits from the other roads and continues toward dubuque as an expressway
lines.name: English

lines.value: this stretch crosses many major rivers including both the wapsipinicon and the maquoketa
lines.name: English

lines.value: the road eventually goes into the driftless area where it meets up with us 61 around the dubuque regional airport
lines.name: English

lines.value: the combined road then heads into the state of wisconsin where it continues with the us 151 name
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 151 concurrent with us 61 crosses the mississippi river into wisconsin via the dubuque wisconsin bridge from dubuque iowa and passes through a cut in the river ridge before turning northward to the western terminus of wis 11 after of due east travel
lines.name: English

lines.value: wis 35 and the great river road join the route at that interchange heading north
lines.name: English

lines.value: the highway at this point is limited access highway with two lanes in each direction
lines.name: English

lines.value: the northward trek of the route passes through mixed residential and farmland as it crosses badger road and merges with eagle point road
lines.name: English

lines.value: eagle point road merges with us 151 from the left side of the road
lines.name: English

lines.value: the limited access portion ends at this interchange
lines.name: English

lines.value: another pair of half diamond interchanges connect the highway with cth hhh and cth h as it bypasses kieler to the northwest
lines.name: English

lines.value: at dickeyville us 61 wis 35 and the great river road route exit north off of us 151 into town
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 151 passes dickeyville to the east and descends into a valley cut northeast of the village paralleling the little platte river and blockhouse creek within the valley for a stretch before climbing back onto the ridgetop on the other side of the valley
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 151 then approaches platteville and enters a section of limited access at cth d us 151 business
lines.name: English

lines.value: the limited access stretch ends after three interchanges and to the east
lines.name: English

lines.value: the last of the interchanges being wis 126/cth g with access to belmont
lines.name: English

lines.value: the route turns northeastward from this point crosses the cottage inn branch and begins the first of several descents into valleys two of which are prior to passing mineral point and another two while passing the city
lines.name: English

lines.value: the highway is limited access between the two interchanges that provide access to mineral point cth o and wis 23
lines.name: English

lines.value: wis 23 joins us 151 heading northbound at that point until the first interchange at dodgeville
lines.name: English

lines.value: this interchange begins another short stretch of freeway to the point where us 18 joins the route
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 18 and us 151 head eastbound past that interchange
lines.name: English

lines.value: the section of expressway past dodgeville passes through rolling hills populated with farmland mixed with small woodlands
lines.name: English

lines.value: the highway passes ridgeway and barneveld
lines.name: English

lines.value: access to ridgeway is by surface intersections with a short business route on cth hhh
lines.name: English

lines.value: however it was announced in 2011 that the first intersection would be closed and an exit would be constructed due to the numerous fatal accidents that happen at the intersection each year
lines.name: English

lines.value: access to barneveld is at an interchange with cth id and an at grade intersection with cth k cth id parallels us 18/us 151 for the entire stretch between barneveld and mount horeb
lines.name: English

lines.value: a section of freeway begins at wis 78 and ends at the other end of cth id as the highway bypasses mount horeb just to the south of the city's passing residential subdivisions
lines.name: English

lines.value: a mix of grade separation and level intersections cross the winding highway as it continues eastward until the interchange with cth mv verona ave begins a section of freeway that bypasses verona to the south
lines.name: English

lines.value: this section provides access to four interchanges including the two endpoints of cth mv
lines.name: English

lines.value: the freeway ends and the route enters an urban multilane highway known as verona road as it passes through fitchburg and into madison
lines.name: English

lines.value: verona road passes through a commercial sector at cth pd and past a residential area on the southwest side of madison
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 18 and us 151 merge east on the west beltline highway - joining us 12 and us 14
lines.name: English

lines.value: the four us routes run concurrently for about to park street
lines.name: English

lines.value: at this interchange us 14 turns south off the beltline towards oregon and us 151 turns north and into central madison us 151 passes monona bay to the west along south park street
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 151 turns northeast onto west washington ave for about 1500 feet then follows proudfit street and north shore drive - paralleling the monona bay shore - and turns north onto john nolen drive
lines.name: English

lines.value: the street passes under the monona terrace convention center as it passes to the south and east of downtown madison
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 151 turns northwest onto south blair street for three city blocks to east washington avenue - where it turns northeast and follows east washington avenue bisecting the madison isthmus and leading out of the city to the east
lines.name: English

lines.value: the left terminus of wis 30 meets us 151 about northeast of the south blair street turn
lines.name: English

lines.value: and us 51 crosses us 151 further northeast
lines.name: English

lines.value: at a cloverleaf interchange with i 39 i 90 and i 94 a section of freeway begins and continues along us 151 northeast through commercial zones into residential areas
lines.name: English

lines.value: the route bypasses sun prairie on the west and north sides through the city's residential zones
lines.name: English

lines.value: after sun prairie us 151 passes through farmland heading toward columbus
lines.name: English

lines.value: the highway bypasses the city via a partial beltline to the north and east completely clearing the city
lines.name: English

lines.value: wis 16 and wis 60 crosses under us 151 about midway along the columbus bypass
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 151 becomes an expressway with level intersections after the interchange with wis 73 at the end of the bypass portion
lines.name: English

lines.value: the route becomes a freeway at beaver dam bypassing the city to the southeast
lines.name: English

lines.value: the route follows the edge of residential zones of the city before passing an industrial area at the northeast end of the bypass
lines.name: English

lines.value: within this freeway section exists a level railroad crossing near cth e east burnett street
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 151 crosses at grade intersections after the interchange with cth a northeast of beaver dam and encounters one more freeway section at waupun bypasses the city to the east
lines.name: English

lines.value: the waupun bypass also includes a level railroad crossing halfway between the cth m and wis 26 interchanges.the four lane expressway of us 151 continues east bypassing fond du lac to the south and east
lines.name: English

lines.value: this expressway provides a mixture of at grade intersections and grade separated interchanges at i 41 and wis 23
lines.name: English

lines.value: wisdot currently is studying upgrades to two sections of us 151
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first study would preserve the fond du lac bypass from i 41 to wis 23 with the ultimate goal being freeway conversion
lines.name: English

lines.value: the second study is examining freeway upgrades to the route from wis 73 in columbus to wis 49 in waupun
lines.name: English

lines.value: the multi lane section of us 151 ends after turning north away from fond du lac and the route follows the east shore of lake winnebago for about half the length of the shoreline
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 151 then turns east at the intersection with wis 55 and follows two lane surface roads and briefly running concurrent with wis 32 and wis 57 in chilton
lines.name: English

lines.value: the roadway passes through farmland throughout this section until it crosses over i 43 and enters manitowoc
lines.name: English

lines.value: the route follows surface streets into manitowoc and terminates in the downtown area at us 10 just blocks prior to the ss badger carferry port
lines.name: English

lines.value: us 151 was one of the original us highways from 1926
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the time it only ran from fond du lac wisconsin to madison
lines.name: English

lines.value: originally the highway ended at western avenue and main street in madison
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1934 the highway was extended southwest to cedar rapids iowa incorporating the full length of former us highway 118 dodgeville to dickeyville and part of former us highway 161 dubuque to cedar rapids us 161 from cedar rapids south to keokuk became us 218
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the time the southern end of the route was at williams blvd sw and 16th ave sw what was then us 30 and us 218
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1940s the highway was extended northeast to manitowoc
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1969 the eagle point bridge which connected us 151 and us 61 with wisconsin was closed and those highways were rerouted over the julien dubuque bridge with us highway 20 from dubuque to east dubuque illinois
lines.name: English

lines.value: the route then followed illinois route 35 and wis 35 north to what is now the current highway
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1982 the dubuque wisconsin bridge opened the old eagle point bridge was demolished and us 151 and us 61 were rerouted onto the new bridge
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is the only instance of us 61 and us 151 entering illinois
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1981 the southern terminus of the highway was extended once again when the us 30 bypass was built
lines.name: English

lines.value: the southern terminus was at the us 151 and 30 interchange
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1986 the main us 151 was rerouted onto state highway 13 and us 30 to bypass cedar rapids
lines.name: English

lines.value: the previous route through cedar rapids was renamed us 151 business though the official state designation for it is iowa 922
lines.name: English

lines.value: finally in 1989 us 151 was extended to its current southern end at exit 225 along i 80
lines.name: English

lines.value: this extension followed the old route of iowa 149
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a result us 151 became the main route through the amana colonies
lines.name: English

lines.value: *us route 51
lines.name: English

lines.value: a defensive coordinator is a coach responsible for a gridiron football american football team's defense
lines.name: English

lines.value: generally the defensive coordinator and the offensive coordinator represent the second level of a team's command structure with the head coach being the first level
lines.name: English

lines.value: the primary role of the defensive coordinator is managing the roster of defensive players overseeing the assistant coaches developing the defensive game plan and calling plays for the defense during the game
lines.name: English

lines.value: the defensive coordinator typically manages multiple assistant coaches each of whom are responsible for various defensive positions on the team such as the defensive line linebackers or defensive backs
lines.name: English

lines.value: while the job of defensive coordinator is largely similar at the collegiate and professional level it is worth noting that college coaches are more involved in the recruitment process
lines.name: English

lines.value: a successful defensive coordinator is often a stepping stone to the position of head coach
lines.name: English

lines.value: other major sports with strong delineation between offensive and defensive positions use similar coaching positions
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example phil housley served as a defensive coordinator for the national hockey league's nashville predators from 2013 to 2017
lines.name: English

lines.value: http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000498479/article/wade-phillips-vic-fangio-among-top-10-defensive-coordinators
lines.name: English

lines.value: shiwa is located in central iwate prefecture in the kitakami river basin south of the prefectural capital of morioka
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sannokai dam is located in shiwa
lines.name: English

lines.value: shiwa has a humid oceanic climate koppen climate classification cfa characterized by mild summers and cold winters
lines.name: English

lines.value: the average annual temperature in shiwa is 10.3 °c
lines.name: English

lines.value: the average annual rainfall is 1326 mm with september as the wettest month and february as the driest month
lines.name: English

lines.value: the temperatures are highest on average in august at around 24.0 °c and lowest in january at around -2.3 °c
lines.name: English

lines.value: per japanese census data the population of shiwa has gradually increased over the past 40 years
lines.name: English

lines.value: the area of present day shiwa was part of ancient mutsu province and has been settled since at least the jomon period
lines.name: English

lines.value: the area was inhabited by the emishi people and came under the control of the yamato dynasty during the early heian period
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the kamakura period the area was ruled by a branch of the northern fujiwara followed by the shiba clan during the muromachi period
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the sengoku period the area was conquered by the nambu clan in 1588
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the edo period shiwa prospered as a post station on the oshu kaido highway connecting edo with the northern provinces as well as from its location on the kitakami river
lines.name: English

lines.value: initially part of morioka domain under the tokugawa shogunate from 1684 four villages tsuchidate katayose inato and kamihirazawa formed an exclave of hachinohe domain
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the meiji period this exclave became the village of shiwa and the town of hizume and the villages of furudate mizuwake akaishi hikobe sahinai akasawa ane nagaoka were established within shiwa district on april 1 1889 with the establishment of the modern municipalities system
lines.name: English

lines.value: these municipalities were merged on april 1 1955 to form the new town of shiwa
lines.name: English

lines.value: the local economy of shiwa is traditionally based on agriculture primarily rice cultivation however due to its proximity to morioka city it is increasingly serving as a bedroom community
lines.name: English

lines.value: shiwa has eleven public elementary schools and three public junior high schools operated by the town government and one public high school operated by the iwate prefectural board of education
lines.name: English

lines.value: the united states constitution names the president of the united states the commander in chief of the us armed forces
lines.name: English

lines.value: previous service in the military is not a prerequisite for the position of president
lines.name: English

lines.value: , no member of the us marine corps or us coast guard has yet been elected president
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most frequent military experience is army/army reserve with 15 presidents followed by state militias at 9 navy/naval reserve at 6 and the continental army with 2 presidents serving

lines.value: eight presidents served during world war ii while seven served in the military during the american civil war

lines.value: the rt 125 was a german two stroke motorcycle made by dkw in zschopau in the 1930s ifa and mz in the 1950s and early 1960s and dkw in ingolstadt in the 1950s and 1960s
lines.name: English

lines.value: rt stands for reichstyp or national model
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1930s dkw pioneered the schnurle two stroke loop scavenging process to dispense with the use of a deflector piston and improve efficiency of the combustion chamber
lines.name: English

lines.value: dkw also developed a highly efficient arrangement of transfer ports
lines.name: English

lines.value: these two features were included in the rt 125 to great commercial advantage
lines.name: English

lines.value: competitor companies such as adler and twn copied the adoption of flat topped pistons and strove to develop equally transfer port arrangements without infringing dkw's patent
lines.name: English

lines.value: copies of the rt 125 were built by at least eight different entities in at least six countries
lines.name: English

lines.value: after world war ii the soviet union took plans tooling and even several dozen personnel as war reparations to mmz in moscow later transferred to mmvz and smz and to a factory in kovrov and produced copies of the rt 125 as the m1a moskva and k 125 respectively
lines.name: English

lines.value: wfm of poland made a modified version of the rt 125 under shl 125 and sokol 125 brands developed into 125/175 cc family motorcycles produced until 1985
lines.name: English

lines.value: rt 125 plans were also taken to the united kingdom where they became the basis of the bsa bantam and to the usa where they formed the basis of the harley davidson hummer"( hummer is really just a few specific years but generally people call the harley lightweights hummers ).
lines.name: English

lines.value: royal enfield also made a variant shipped under the name of indian which had ceased in 1956 called the indian lance of 150cc displacement in size
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the second world war dkw's factories in zschopau were in the soviet occupation zone
lines.name: English

lines.value: as such they were under the control of the soviet union until they were handed over to the government of east germany
lines.name: English

lines.value: the factory continued production of the rt 125 under the mz motorradwerk zschopau brand into the 1950s
lines.name: English

lines.value: meanwhile dkw had reorganized itself in ingolstadt where it began production of the rt 125w for west in 1949
lines.name: English

lines.value: variants of the rt 125w usually with larger engines were in production throughout the 1950s
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1950s after reestablishing themselves as manufacturers of musical instruments nippon gakki decided to use the manufacturing equipment left over from wartime production to make motorcycles
lines.name: English

lines.value: since the copyright on the rt 125 had been voided by the allies the company reverse engineered it as the basis for their first motorcycle
lines.name: English

lines.value: nippon gakki formed the yamaha motor company in 1955 to build their copy of the rt 125 as the yamaha ya 1 which was in production from 1955 to 1958
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ya 1 inherited design characteristics of rt 125 and due to its thin body and chestnut brown tank was affectionately nicknamed the
lines.name: English

lines.value: rock against howard musicians against the liberal government is an australian compilation cd featuring anti coalition musicians released in 2004
lines.name: English

lines.value: the project hoped to inspire young voters to turn out in federal elections that year to vote against then prime minister john howard but howard's party prevailed all the same
lines.name: English

lines.value: rock against howard was organised by frenzal rhomb guitarist lindsay mcdougall when he realised every musician he knew felt the same way about howard
lines.name: English

lines.value: mcdougall told daniel johnson of the age that i wanted to get more and different music fans and acts in on the idea of rock against howard and it also adequately reflects my taste in music because i've got a bunch of my favourite bands on here as well the project was inspired by the american rock against bush compilations and takes on a similar format
lines.name: English

lines.value: all profits from album sales go to refugee charities through the refugee action coalition an ironic tribute to howard's stance on asylum seekers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the music on the release is politically oriented with the first disk featuring previously released songs and a disk of live and otherwise previously unreleased work on the second
lines.name: English

lines.value: the style of music varies widely with punk rock hip hop and even show tunes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the complete u2 is a digital box set by irish rock band u2
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was released on 23 november 2004 by apple computer on the itunes store
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is the first major release of a purely digital online set by any artist
lines.name: English

lines.value: it contained the complete set of u2 albums singles live rare and previously unreleased material from 1978 to 2004 with a total of 446 songs
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was accompanied by a pdf containing album art track listings and band commentary
lines.name: English

lines.value: it originally retailed for $149.99 but a $50 coupon was included with the u2 special edition ipods from the fourth generation ipod
lines.name: English

lines.value: the video capable u2 ipods included a code for a 33-minute video of live band performances and interviews
lines.name: English

lines.value: as of 20 december 2007 the set is no longer available for sale
lines.name: English

lines.value: the following albums are only officially available as part of this set
lines.name: English

lines.value: early demos is an ep containing three demos produced by barry devlin and recorded at keystone studios in april 1978
lines.name: English

lines.value: these songs are the band's second recorded studio work
lines.name: English

lines.value: street mission and the fool have not been on any other album
lines.name: English

lines.value: shadows and tall trees was the final track on their first studio album boy released in 1980
lines.name: English

lines.value: live from boston 1981 is a live album recorded during u2's boy tour at boston's paradise rock club on march 6 1981
lines.name: English

lines.value: some of the tracks on this album have been originally released on other singles previous to the release of this album
lines.name: English

lines.value: live from the point depot is the first official release of the band's widely bootlegged new year's eve show at dublin's point depot in 1989
lines.name: English

lines.value: unreleased & rare is a compilation of unreleased and rare tracks
lines.name: English

lines.value: most of the previously unreleased songs were from the band's all that you can't leave behind and how to dismantle an atomic bomb sessions
lines.name: English

lines.value: the album medium rare & remastered released in 2009 contains similar tracks
lines.name: English

lines.value: goyang kb kookmin bank fc () was a south korean football club based in the seoul satellite city of goyang
lines.name: English

lines.value: it played in the national league the third tier of korean football
lines.name: English

lines.value: the club was officially dissolved in november 2012
lines.name: English

lines.value: kookmin bank fc was initially founded on september,1969 and competed in the various amateur football competitions at the time
lines.name: English

lines.value: the club enjoyed success in tournaments such as the korea semi professional football league winners in 1978 and the president's cup winners in 1978 and 1983 before becoming founder members of the k league the professional football league in south korea in 1983
lines.name: English

lines.value: the club's stay in the professional ranks was a short one as it finished 5th out of the five teams in the first year
lines.name: English

lines.value: when it came in 8th out of the eight teams in 1984 the decision was made for the club to return to the amateur ranks
lines.name: English

lines.value: upon returning to the amateur ranks the club returned to winning ways and managed president's cup triumphs in 1986 1990 and 1995
lines.name: English

lines.value: it also won the 3rd edition of the industrial amateur football championship in 1993 a tournament they would win again in 1996
lines.name: English

lines.value: the financial crisis that struck south korea in 1997 saw the club temporarily wound up with the official decision to pull the plug on the team coming on december 31 1997
lines.name: English

lines.value: after two years out of the game kookmin bank reconstituted their club on february 28 2000 and the team returned to the amateur ranks eventually winning a sixth president's cup crown in 2003
lines.name: English

lines.value: organised league football at amateur level came about in 2003 with the establishment of the national league a competition with ten members of which kookmin bank were one
lines.name: English

lines.value: initially based in gimpo the club won the first stage of the 2003 championship and then moved its home base to goyang and the team's name was changed to goyang kookmin bank for the second stage where they finished runners up on goal difference
lines.name: English

lines.value: they defeated the reserve team of military side sangmu 5-4 on aggregate in the playoff final to win the league
lines.name: English

lines.value: they retained their championship crown in 2004 with a 4-1 aggregate win over gangneung city fc after having again won the first stage of the league season
lines.name: English

lines.value: despite a lacklustre 2005 season the club bounced back to win the 2006 championship now rebranded the national league] triumphing 2-1 on aggregate in the final after winning the first stage of the season
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was planned that subject to meeting certain financial requirements the winner of the national league in 2006 would be promoted to the k league
lines.name: English

lines.value: however goyang kookmin bank caused controversy by winning the league but declining to move up
lines.name: English

lines.value: team owners kookmin bank cited a korean law where banks in korea were not allowed to be involved in profitable ventures outside of banking which of course a professional football team could be
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the more likely reason is the large financial losses that most k league teams endure each year as the league struggles for sponsorship money and suffers through low crowd numbers
lines.name: English

lines.value: on top of that any national league champion seeking promotion from the second tier is required to pay an entry fee of around 2 million us dollars simply to join the league
lines.name: English

lines.value: goyang kookmin bank received several threats from the league ranging from being thrown out of the competition to fines to point deductions for the upcoming 2007 season
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the end the side received a points deduction penalty to be split into ten point deductions in the first and second stages of the 2007 season
lines.name: English

lines.value: 1 goyang kb kookmin bank was docked 10 points due to rejecting of promotion
lines.name: English

lines.value: marand (; ; also romanized as morand is a city and capital of marand county east azerbaijan province iran
lines.name: English

lines.value: marand is among major cities in the province
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is located in the north west of capital of the province tabriz
lines.name: English

lines.value: marand has been known by various names in history such as maryana mandagarana and maranda
lines.name: English

lines.value: moritz von kotzebue and august von haxthausen both described local legends that placed the burial spot of noah's wife at marand
lines.name: English

lines.value: both authors contended that the name of the city means the mother lies here referring to noah's wife
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to kotzebue
lines.name: English

lines.value: the history of the town goes back to the pre islamic era
lines.name: English

lines.value: between 815 till 850 marand was primarily controlled by mohammad ibn ba'ith who was iranicized to a considerable extent
lines.name: English

lines.value: the elders of maragha who quoted his persian poetry also praised his bravery and his literatry ability
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was iranicized to considerable extent and the statement of tabari on him is evidence of the existence of the cultivation of poetry in persian in northwest persia at the beginning of the 9th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: during february 2010 it was reported that an attack was carried out in the city of marand against a truck which was carrying tear gas and other substances for the use of the iranian revolutionary guards
lines.name: English

lines.value: the iran liberation front claimed responsibility for the attack through a video posted on youtube
lines.name: English
